editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: Sales Epigrammatum: Being the CHOICEST DISTICKS OF MARTIALS Fourteen BOOKS of Epigrams; And of all the Chief LATINE POETS That have writ in theſe Two laſt CENTURIES. Together with CATO'S MORALITY.

q.p:
Quo vis cun
que loco potes hunc finire Libellum, Verſibus explicitum eſt omne duobus opus.

div.p: London, Printed by T. R. for Chriſtopher Eccleſton, in St. Dunſtans Church-yard. 1663.

div.head: TO THE RIGHT WORSHIPFUL SIR William Bromley, Knight of the Honourable Order OF THE BATH.
div.p:
IT hath been the approved Cuſtome of moſt Authors, that when their private Notions are to appear, and be preſſed for publick ſervice, to chuſe out of the liſt
of their friends, ſome noble and worthy Perſonage under the conduct of whoſe name, they may march into the world. Wherefore I have in this Dedication, not improperly, made choice of you, who are your ſelf a chief Favorite of the Muſes. One who underſtands the Original as well as the Copy; and could perceive and cenſure a fault (if poſſible) in Martial, or Grotius himſelf, with as much facility as in this Tranſlation. Which Tranſlation, if it ſhall gain your fair opinion, I know none of like worth and Ingenuity with your ſelf, will differ from your cenſure: As for thoſe of a contrary character, I ſhall value neither their applauſe, nor diſcommendation.
Briefly, Sir, your candid acceptation of this piece, will add to your former favours; and by a new Obligation engage me ever to remain, what I have ever been,

div.head: To the READER.
div.p: GEnerally in Epigrams of ſix, eight, or ten verſes, the Salt, the Conceipt of all is referred to a Distick in the end, and there expreſſed: Thus you ſee Diſticks in general, are Sales Epigrammatum; wherefore, I hope, thou wilt not think this title improperly applied to this piece, which is a collection of the choicest.

Thou mayst perchance be pleaſed with my Verſion; if not in all, yet in ſome places: If not in any, yet I am ſure no lover of ingenuous Poeſie can diſlike the Original. Wonder not to ſee me deviate from the letter in this Tranſlation, it being either to heighthen or clear the Conceipt: For it is Quintilians advice, Neque
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
eſſe interpretationem tantum volo, ſed circa eoſdem ſenſus certamen atque aemulationem. And it is Mr. Cowleys opinion, That Tranſlators ſhould add all that they can by their own Wit and Invention, not deſerting the ſubject; and thus he proceeds, The not obſerving of this, is the cauſe that all Tranſlations that I ever yet ſaw, are ſo much inferior to their
Originals. The like happens too in Pictures from the ſame root of exact imitation, which being a vile and unworthy kind of ſervitude, is incapable of producing any thing good or noble. Not to quote more, this is the judgement of theſe two great Wits, which must not be excepted against; nor will be by any who know what belongs to Poetry.
And now, Reader, proceed to examine freely, but cenſure favourably the following Tranſlation of

lg.head: Epigram XVII. To Avitus.
lg.l: THere are ſome good, more bad, whereon you look:
Avitus, without this, 'tis not a Book.

lg.head: Epigram XXIX. Of Acerra.
lg.l: Who ſays with laſt nights Wine Acerra ſtinks,
Is much deceived; till day Acerra drinks.

lg.head: Epig. XXXIII. To Sabidius.
lg.l: I love thee not Sabidius; Ask you why?
I do not love thee, let that ſatisfie.

lg.head: Epig. XXXIX. To Fidentinus.
lg.l: This Book you read, O Fidentine, is mine:
But when you ill rehearſe it, then tis thine.

lg.head: Epig. XLI. To Lividus.
lg.l: Who with knit brows read'ſt theſe: for ever be
So low, that thou may'ſt envy all, none thee.

lg.head: Epig. XLVIII. Of Diaulus the Phyſitian.
lg.l: Diaul the Dectour is a Sexton made;
Though he is changed, he changeth not his Trade.

lg.head: Epig. LXXVI. Of Lynus.
lg.l: Who half to Lynus give, then lend all, choſe;
Had rather half, then all their money loſe.

lg.head: Epig. XCII. To Laelius.
lg.l: My Verſe you judge, yet publiſh not your own;
Laelius, carp not at ours, or yours make known.

lg.head: Epig. XCVI. To Helius.
lg.l: Since you baul always, hindering thoſe that plead,
You get, by't; for to hold your peace you'r feed.

lg.head: Epig. XCIX. To Flaccus.
lg.l: The Law and Foot-gout troubles Diodore;
No Lawyers feed, this is the hand-gout ſure.

lg.head: Epig. CI. Of old Afra.
lg.l: Afra both Mams and Daddies hath; yet ſhe
The Dad of Dads, and Mam of Mams may be.

lg.head: Epig. CXI. To Velox.
lg.l: You ſay my Epigrams, Velox, too long are;
You nothing write; ſure yours are ſhorter far.

lg.head: Epig. CXIII. On Priſcus.
lg.l: While not yet known, I lord and king call'd thee;
Well known, you are plain Priſcus now to me.

lg.head: Epig. CXIX. To Caecilianus.
lg.l: A hundred read, you think too few I gave
Of Epigrams; Wilt thou more evils have?

lg.head: Epigram XVII. Ad Avitum.
lg.l: Sunt Bona, ſunt quaedam mediocria, ſunt mala plura
Quae legis hic: aliter non fit, Avite, liber.

lg.head: Epigram XXIX. De Acerra.
lg.l: Heſterno foetere mero qui credit Acerram,
Fallitur; in lucem ſemper Acerra bibit.

lg.head: Epig. XXXIII. Ad Sabidium.
lg.l: Non amo te Sabidi, nec poſſum dicere quare;
Hoc tantum poſſum dicere, Non amo te.

lg.head: Epig. XXXIX. Ad Fidentinum.
lg.l: Quem recitas, meus eſt, ô Fidentine, libellus:
Sed malè cùm recitas, incipit eſſe cuus.

lg.head: Epig. XLI. Ad Lividum.
lg.l: Qui ducis vultus, & non legis iſta libenter,
Omnibus invideas, Livide, nemo tibi.

lg.head: Epig. XLVIII. De Diaulo medico.
lg.l: Nuper erat medicus, nunc eſt veſpillo Diaulus;
Quod veſpillo facit, fecerat & medicus.

lg.head: Epig, LXXVI. De Lyno.
lg.l: Dimidium donare Lino, quam credere totum,
Qui mavult: mavult perdere dimidium.

lg.head: Epig. XCII. Ad Laelium.
lg.l: Cum tua non edas, carpis mea carmina, Laeli;
Carpere vel noli nostra, vel ede tua.

lg.head: Epig. XCVI. Ad Helium.
lg.l: Quod clamas ſemper, quod agentibus obſtrepis Heli,
Non facis hoc gratis: accipis, ut taceas.

lg.head: Epig. XCIX. Ad Flaccum.
lg.l: Litigat, & podagra Diodorus Flacce laborat;
Sed nil patrono porrigit, haec chiragra eſt.

lg.head: Epig. CI. De Afra vetula.
lg.l: Mammas at que tatas habet Afra: ſed ipſa tatarum
Dici & mammarum maxima mamma poteſt.

lg.head: Epig. CXI. Ad Velocem.
lg.l: Scribere me quereris, Velox, epigrammata longa;
Ipſe nihil ſcribis, tu breviora facis.

lg.head: Epig. CXIII. In Priſcum.
lg.l: Cum te non noſſem, dominum regemque vocabam:
Cum bent te novi, jam mihi Priſcus eris.

lg.head: Epig. CXIX. Ad Caecilianum.
lg.l: Cui legiſſe ſat is, non eſt epigrammata centum,
Nil illi ſatis eſt, Caeciliane, mali.

lg.head: Epig. III. To Sextus.
lg.l: YOu nothing owe, you nothing owe, we know:
Sextus, to pay he's able, that doth owe.

lg.head: Epig. XIII. To Sextus.
lg.l: Both Judge and Advocate look for reward,
'Tis my mind with your Creditor you accord.

lg.head: Epig. XV. Upon Hermus.
lg.l: That you your cup to drink do give to none:
Hermus' tis civilly, not proudly done.

lg.head: Epig. XX. Of Paulus.
lg.l: Bought Verſes, for his own, Paul doth recite;
For what you buy, you may call yours by right.

lg.head: Epig. XXI. Upon Poſthumus.
lg.l: You kiſs ſome, Poſthume, ſome your hand allow;
You bid me chuſe; your hand, your hand I vow.

lg.head: Epig. XXV. to Galla.
lg.l: You nere give, Galla, yet grant conſtantly;
If that's your way, I'le beg what you'd deny.

lg.head: Epig. XXVIII. Upon Linus.
lg.l: Ask you what my Nomentine field brings me?
This Linus 'mongſt the reſt, I nere ſee thee.

lg.head: Epig. LVIII. Upon Zoilus.
lg.l: You ſprucely cloathed, laugh at my thred-bare gown;
'Tis thred-bare truly, Zoilus, but mine own.

lg.head: Epig. LXXX. Of Fannius.
lg.l: When Fannius from his Enemy did fly,
He kild himſelf for fear leſt he ſhould die.

lg.head: LXXXVIII. Upon Mamercus.
lg.l: You'd Poet ſeem, yet nothing you rehearſe;
Be what you will, ſo we nere hear your verſe.

lg.head: Epig. III. Ad Sextum.
lg.l: SExte, nihil debes; nil debes, Sexte, fatemur:
Debet enim, ſi quis ſolvere, Sexte, poteſt.

lg.head: Epig. XIII. Ad Sextum.
lg.l: Et Judex petit, & petit patronus;
Solvas cenſeo, Sexte, creditori.

lg.head: Epig. XV. In Hermum.
lg.l: Quod nulli calicem tuum propinas,
Humanè facis, Herme, non ſuperbè.

lg.head: Epig. XX. De Paullo
lg.l: Carmina Paullus emit: recitat ſua carmina Paullus.
Nam quod emis, poſſis dicere jure tuum.

lg.head: Epig. XXI. In Poſthumum.
lg.l: Baſia das aliis, aliis das, Poſthume, dextram.
Dicis, utrum mavis? elige: malo manum.

lg.head: Epig. XXV. Ad Gallam.
lg.l: Das nunquam, ſemper promitis, Galla, roganti;
Si ſemper fallis, jam rogo, Galla, nega.

lg.head: Epig. XXXVIII. In Linum.
lg.l: Quid mihi reddat ager, quaeris, Linc, Nomentanus?
Hoc mihi reddit ager: te Line non video.

lg.head: Epig. LII. In Zoilum.
lg.l: Pexatus pulchrè, rides mea, Zoile, trita:
Sunt haec trita quidem, Zoiele, ſed mea ſunt.

lg.head: Epig. LXXX. De Fannio.
lg.l: Hoſtem cùm fugeret, ſe Fannius ipſe peremit:
Hic rogo, non faror eſt, ne moriare mori?

lg.head: Epig. LXXXVIII. In Mamercum.
lg.l: Nil recitas, & vis, Mamerce, Poeta videri:
Quicquid vis eſto, dummodo nil recites.

lg.head: Epig. VIII. Upon Quintus.
lg.l: Quiatus loves Thais: Which Thais? Is it ſhe
That's blind? I think ſhe hath more eyes then he.

lg.head: Epig. IX. Upon Cinna.
lg.l: Cinna on me Verſes to write is ſaid;
He writes not, who's not worthy to be read.

lg.head: Epig. XXI. On a cruel Maſter.
lg.l: Who ſav'd by his man, doth ſtigmatize the ſame,
Returns himſelf to baniſh his good name.

lg.head: Epig. XXVIII. Upon Neſtor.
lg.l: Wonder you Neſtor, Marius ear ſmells ſtrong?
Your breaths the Cauſe, you whiſper there ſo long.

lg.head: Epig. XXXV. Of fiſhes engraved.
lg.l: Theſe fiſhes ſee, that the fain'd ſculpture are
Of Phidias; adde but water, they'l ſwim there.

lg.head: Epig. XXXVII. On angry friends.
lg.l: Rich friends 'gainſt poor, to anger ſtill are prone;
It is not well, but profitably done.

lg.head: Epig. XLI. Of a Lizard engrav'd upon a Cup.
lg.l: The Lizard wrought by Mentor's hand ſo rare,
Was fear'd in th' Cup, as though it living were.

lg.head: Epig. XLIX. Upon the Invitor.
lg.l: You Maſſick drink, Veian wine give to me:
I need not taſt, the ſmell doth ſatisfie.

lg.head: Epig. LVI. Of the water of Ravenna.
lg.l: I'de rather have a Well at Rhene, than Vine:
Since Water there is far more dear then Wine.

lg.head: Epig. LXI. Upon Cinna.
lg.l: What e're you ask, 'tis Nothing ſtill you cry;
If Nothing Cinna, Nothing I'le deny.

lg.head: Epig. LXXXIX. To Phoebus.
lg.l: Lettuces, Phoebus, and ſoft Mallows uſe:
Thy coſtive ſqueezing Cloſeſtool-face to looſe.

lg.head: Epig. XCIV. On Rufus.
lg.l: You ſay you Hare's not boyl'd, and ſeem to be
Enrag'd: you'd flaſh your Cook, not Hare I ſee.

lg.head: Epig. VIII. In Quintum.
lg.l: Thaida Quintus amat: quam Thaida? Thaida luſcam.
Unum oculum Thais non habet, ille duos.

lg.head: Epig. IX. In Cinnam.
lg.l: Verſiculos in me narratur ſcribere Cinna.
Non ſcribit, cujus carmina nemo legit.

lg.head: Epig. XXI. In crudelem Dominum.
lg.l: Proſcriptum famulus ſervavit fronte notatus;
Non fuit haec domini vita, ſed invidia.

lg.head: Epig. XXVIII. In Neſtorem.
lg.l: Auriculam Mario graviter miraris olere:
Tu facis hoc: garris, Neſtor, in auriculam.

lg.head: Epig. XXXV. De Piſcibus ſculptis.
lg.l: Art is Phidiacae toreuma clarum,
Piſces adſpicis: adde aquam, natabunt.

lg.head: Epig. XXXVII. In iraſcentes amicos.
lg.l: Iraſci tantùm felicis noſtis amici;
Non bellè facitis: ſed juvat boc facere.

lg.head: Epig. XLI. In lacerta caelata.
lg.l: Inſerta Phialae Mentoris manu ducta
Lacerta vivit, & timetur argentum.

lg.head: Epig. XLIX. Ad Invitatorem.
lg.l: Veientana mihi miſces, tu Maſſica potas:
Olfacere haec malo pocula, quàm bibere.

lg.head: Epig. LVI. De Ciſterna Ravennate.
lg.l: Sit ciſterna mihi, quàm vinea, malo Ravennae:
Cùm poſſim multo vendere pluris aquam.

lg.head: Epig. LXI. In Cinnam.
lg.l: Eſſe nihil dicis, quidquid petis, improbe Cinna.
Si nil Cinna petis, nil tibi, Cinna, nego.

lg.head: Epig. LXXXIX. Ad Phaebum.
lg.l: Utere lactucis, & mollibus utere malvis:
Nam faciem durùm, Phaebe, cacantis habet.

lg.head: Epig. XCIV. In Rufum.
lg.l: Mavis Rufe coquum ſcindere, quàm leporem.

lg.head: Epig. XXIV. To Fabianus.
lg.l: Licoris of her Friends ſtill makes an end;
I would ſhe were to my Wife ſuch a Friend.

lg.head: Epig. XXXIV. To Attalus.
lg.l: Thy Gown is thred-bare, ſoil'd; yet he ſaith right,
O Attalus, that ſaith thy Gown is white.

lg.head: Epig. XLI. Of a bad Poet.
lg.l: Why wrapt about your Neck Wool do you wear?
That Wool would better ſerve to ſtop your Ear.

lg.head: Epig. XLVII. Of Phaeton.
lg.l: There Phaeton ſee, wrought with a burning ſtile;
What do you mean? him to twice burn the while.

lg.head: Epig. LXV. Of Philaenis.
lg.l: With but one eye Philaenis weeps; how done
If you enquire, know ſhe hath got but one.

lg.head: Epig. LXXVI. To his covetous Friend.
lg.l: I ask'd Twelve thouſand Seſterce, Six you gave:
Henceforth I'le double ask what I would have.

lg.head: Epig. LXXX. To Matho.
lg.l: So conſtant Gueſt unto my farm y'are known;
You buying it, I cheat, and ſell your own.

lg.head: Epig. LXXXVI. Upon Ponticus.
lg.l: We drink in glaſs, but you in ſtone, and why?
Leaſt clear glaſs ſhould your better Wine deſcry.

lg.head: Epig. XXIV. Ad Fabianum.
lg.l: Omnes, quas habuit, Fabiane, Lycoris amicas
Extulit; uxori fiat amica meae.

lg.head: Epig. XXXIV. Ad Attalum.
lg.l: Sordida cùm tibi ſit: verum tamen, Attale, dicit
Quiſquis'te niveam dicit habere togam.

lg.head: Epig. XLI. In male recitantem.
lg.l: Quid recitaturus circundas vellera collo?
Conveniunt nostris auribus illa magis.

lg.head: Epig. XLVII. De Phaetone.
lg.l: Eacauſtus Phaeton tabulâ depictus in hac eſt.
Quid tibi vis, dipyron qui Phaethonta facis?

lg.head: Epig. LXV. De Philaeni.
lg.l: Oculo Philaenis ſemper altero plorat.
Quo fiat iſtud quaeritis modo, luſca eſt.

lg.head: Epig. LXXVI. In avarum amicum.
lg.l: Millia miſiſti mihi ſex, bis ſena petenti:
Ut bis ſena feram, bis duodena petam.

lg.head: Epig. LXXX. Ad Mathonem.
lg.l: Hoſpes eras noſtri ſemper, Matho, Tiburtini:
Hoc emis, impoſui, rus tibi vendo tuum.

lg.head: Epig. LXXXVI. In Ponticum.
lg.l: Non bibimus nitro, tu myrrhâ, Pontice; quare?
Prodat perſpicuus ne duo vina calix.

lg.head: Epig. XXXIII. Of Criſp.
lg.l: Criſpus no fourth part to his Wife did leave;
Unto whom then? himſelf did it receive.

lg.head: Epig. XLIV. Of Thais and Lecania.
lg.l: Lecania's teeth why white, Thais black are?
Lecania bought, Thais her own doth wear.

lg.head: Epig. XLVIII. Of Philo.
lg.l: That he ne're ſups at home, Philo makes Oath;
He never ſups, but when invited forth.

lg.head: Epig. LVIII. To Cinna.
lg.l: When Sir I call thee, be not pleas'd; for know
Cinna, I often call my ſervant ſo.

lg.head: Epig. LXXXII. To Aemilianus.
lg.l: You want, Aemilianus, ſo you may:
Riches are given rich men, and none but they.

lg.head: Epig. LXXXIV. To Dindymus.
lg.l: I fly, you follow; fly, when I perſue:
What I love, hate, is hated, lov'd by you.

lg.head: Epig. XXXIII. De Criſpo.
lg.l: Quadrantem Criſpus tabulis, Fauſtine, ſupremis
Non dedit uxori; cui dedit ergo? ſibi.

lg.head: Epig. XLIV. De Thaide & Lecania.
lg.l: Thais habet nigros, niveos Lecania dentes.
Quae ratio eſt? emptos haec habet, illa ſuos.

lg.head: Epig. XLVIII. De Philone.
lg.l: Nunquam ſe coenaſſe domi Philo jurat: & hoc eſt:
Non coenat quoties nemo vocavit eum.

lg.head: Epig. LVIII. Ad Cinnam.
lg.l: Cum voco te Dominum, noli tibi, Cinna, placere:
Saepe etiam ſervum ſic reſaluto meum.

lg.head: Epig. LXXXII. Ad Aemilianum.
lg.l: Semper eris pauper, ſi pauper es, Aemiliane:
Dantur opes nulli nunc niſi divitibus.

lg.head: Epig. LXXXIV. Ad Dindymum.
lg.l: Inſequeris, fugio; fugis, inſequor: haec mihi mens eſt:
Velle tuum nolo, Dindyme, nolle volo.

lg.head: Epig. XLVIII. On Pomponius.
lg.l: Sophos to thee thy Clients cry; but know
Thy Supper's eloquent, Thou art not ſo.

lg.head: Epig. LXXIX. To Lupus.
lg.l: What fad, and rich? beware, if Fortune ſhall,
Lupus, know this, ſhe'le thee ingratefull call.

lg.head: Epig. XC. Of Gellia.
lg.l: Gellia hath but one Servant, yet much ſhame:
For Gellia hath two Husbands; there's the blame.

lg.head: Epig. XLVIII. In Pomponium.
lg.l: Quòd tam grande ſophos clamat tibi turba togata,
Non tu, Pompini, caena diſerta tua eſt.

lg.head: Epig. LXXIX. Ad Lupum.
lg.l: Triſtis es, & felix; ſciat hoc fortuna caveto:
Ingratum dicet te, Lupe, ſi ſcierit.

lg.head: Epig. XC. De Gellia.
lg.l: Moechum Gellia non habet niſi unum:
Turpe eſt hoc magis; uxor eſt duorum.

lg.head: Epig. II. To Pontilianus.
lg.l: Why ſend I not to thee theſe Books of mine?
'Cauſe I, Pontilian, would be free from thine.

lg.head: Epig. VIII. Of Caſſelius.
lg.l: Caſſelius now to threeſcore years doth riſe;
He witty is, when will he grow to wiſe?

lg.head: Epig. XV To Regulus.
lg.l: Having no mony, I am forc'd your Pack
Of Gifts to ſell; what, Regulus, do ye lack?

lg.head: Epig. LVIII. Of Caecilianus.
lg.l: Without a Bore Caecilian ne're doth feaſt;
Titus, he hath a very pretty Gueſt.

lg.head: Epig. LXV. Of Labienus.
lg.l: Fábius left Labien his ſole Heir by will;
Yet he complains he is a Looſer ſtill.

lg.head: Epig. LXXVI. Of Tucca.
lg.l: Ask me no more, no Books I'le give to thee;
Tucca, you ſell, not read the Courteſie.

lg.head: Epig. LXXX. To Lauſus.
lg.l: Thirty Bad Epigrams the Book doth ſhare;
The Book is good, if Thirty good there are.

lg.head: Epig. LXXXII. Of Eutrapelus.
lg.l: Barber Eutrapelus did ſhave ſo ſlow
Lupercus Chin; another Beard did grow.

lg.head: Epig. XCIII. To Papilus.
lg.l: Sweet oyntment once was in that Onyx ſtone;
You ſmelt, and ſee 'tis putrefaction grown.

lg.head: Epig. C. Of an Old Woman.
lg.l: If touch'd, or heard, you pleaſe; not ſeen each part
Doth pleaſe us well; none, if in ſight thou art.

lg.head: Epig. II. Ad Pontilianum.
lg.l: Cur non mitto meos tibi, Pontiliane, libellos?
Ne mihi tu mittas, Pontiliane, tuos.

lg.head: Epig. VIII. De Caſſelio.
lg.l: Cum ſexaginta numeret Caſſelius annos,
Ingenioſus homo eſt: quando diſertus erit?

lg.head: Epig. XV. Ad Regulum.
lg.l: Aera domi non ſunt; ſupereſt hoc, Regule, tantùm,
Ut tua vendamus munera: numquid emis?

lg.head: Epig. LVIII. De Caeciliano.
lg.l: Non coenát ſine apro noſter, Tite, Caecilianus,
Bellum convivam Caecilianus habet.

lg.head: Epig. LXV. De Labieno.
lg.l: Haeredem Fabius Labienum ex aſſe reliquit:
Plus meruiſſe tamen ſe Labienus ait.

lg.head: Epig. LXXVI. In Tuccam.
lg.l: Exigis ut noſtros donem tibi, Tucca libellos;
Non faciam: nam vis vendere, non legere.

lg.head: Epig. LXXX. Ad Lauſum.
lg.l: Triginta toto mala ſunt epigrammata, libro:
Si totidem bona ſunt, Lauſe, liber bonus eſt.

lg.head: Epig. LXXXII. De Eutrapelo:
lg.l: Eutrapelus tonſor dum circuit ora Luperci,

Expungit
que genas: altera barba ſubit.

lg.head: Epig. XCIII. De Papilo.
lg.l: Unguentum fuerat, quod onyx modò parva gerebat:
Olfecit poſtquam Papilus, ecce garum eſt.

lg.head: Epig. C. De Vetula.
lg.l: Tacta places, audita places, ſi non videare,
Tota places: neutro, ſi videare, places.

lg.head: Epig. XXVII. To Gaurus.
lg.l: Who gives you gifts being rich, and old, doth cry,
Gaurus, To thee I give theſe gifts to dy.

lg.head: Epig. XXIX. Of Diſticks.
lg.l: What Writer can as ſhort on Diſticks look,
When even thoſe Diſticks do make up a Book?

lg.head: Epig. XLIX. Of Aſper.
lg.l: One that is fair, blind Aſper much eſteems;
Yet Asper ſees not what he does, it ſeems.

lg.head: Epig. LX. Of Claudia.
lg.l: The Palatine Coloſſus Claudia muſt,
If eighteen inches ſhorter, equal juſt.

lg.head: Epig. XXVII. Ad Gaurum.
lg.l:
Munera qui tibi dat locupleti, Gaure, ſeni
que
Si ſapis & ſentis, hic tibi ait, Morere.

lg.head: Epig. XXIX. De Diſtichis.
lg.l: Diſticha qui ſcribit, puto, vult brevitate placere.
Quid prodeſt brevitas, dic mihi ſi, liber eſt?

lg.head: Epig. XLIX. De Aſpro.
lg.l: Formoſam planè, ſed coecus diliget Aſper:
Plus ergo, ut res eſt, quàm videt Aſper, amat.

lg.head: Epíg. LX. In Claudiam.
lg.l: Summa Palatini poteras aequare Coloſſi,
Si fieres brevior, Claudia, ſeſquipede.

lg.head: Epig. VI. On Paula.
lg.l: You'd Priſcus wed, Paula; you're wiſe I know;
But hee'l not thee; Priſcus is wiſer though.

lg.head: Epig. XVI. Of Chloe.
lg.l: On her ſeven Husbands tombs ſhe doth impreſs,
This Chloë did; what can ſhe more confeſs?

lg.head: Epig. XCVII. Of Herodes.
lg.l: Stealing his Cup, his Patient him did ſpy;
Herodes ſaid, Fool, if you drink you dy.

lg.head: Epig. VI. In Paullam.
lg.l: Nubere vis Priſco, non miror, Paulla: ſapíſti.
Ducere te non vult Priſcus: & ílle ſpit.

lg.head: Epig. XVI. De Chloë.
lg.l: Inſcripſit tumulo ſeptem celebrata virorum
Se feciſſe Chloë: quid pote ſimplicius?

lg.head: Epig. XCVII. De Herode.
lg.l: Clinicus Herodes trullam ſubduxerat aegro:
Deprenſus dixit; ſtulte, quid ergo bibis?

lg.head: Epig. VIII. Of Paulla.
lg.l: Paulla would marry me, ſhe is too old;
Yet were ſhe not ſo young, the match ſhould hold.

lg.head: Epig. XLIII. To Phileros.
lg.l: Now in thy field ſeven Wives buried are;
What ground than thine a better crop doth bear?

lg.head: Epig. LIV. Upon Olus.
lg.l: Your Feaſt ſtill cover'd is: I, Olus, ſure,
If this be one, a Feaſt can make, though poor.

lg.head: Epig. LXXXIV. Of Afer to Caecilianus.
lg.l: Reaſon why Afer ſleeps not you would know;
Caecilianus, mind his Bed-fellow.

lg.head: Epig. VIII. De Paulla.
lg.l: Nubere Paulla cupit nobis, ego ducere Paullam
Nolo: anus est; vellem ſi magis eſſet anus.

lg.head: Epig. XLIII. Ad Philerotem.
lg.l: Septima jam, Phileros, ìibi conditur uxor in agro.
Plus nulli, Phileros, quàm tibi reddit ager.

lg.head: Epig. LIV. In Olum.
lg.l: Menſas, Ole, bonas ponis: ſed ponis opertas.
Ridiculum eſt poſſum ſic ego habere bonas.

lg.head: Epig. LXXXIV. De Afro, ad Caecilianum:
lg.l: Miraris, quare dormitum non eat Afer?
Accumbat cum qua Caeciliane vides.

lg.head: Epig. XV. Of a little Farmer.
lg.l: Entomb this ſmall Aërial Corps ith' sky;
On him the leaſt earth will too heavy ly.

lg.head: Epig. LXVIII. Upon Maro.
lg.l: Living you nothing give; your Funeral fire
You ſay, gives all; you know what I deſire.

lg.head: Epig. LXIX. To Matho.
lg.l: Great men deny when trifles you'd receive;
With leſſe ſhame ask what befits them to give.

lg.head: Epig. LXXXIV. To Soſibianus.
lg.l: Gratis none lodge, but rich, and Orphanes thoſe,
Who on his houſe doth dearer rates impoſe.

lg.head: Epig. XCIII. Upon Zoilus.
lg.l: Who calls thee Vitious, lyes; You, Zoilus, are
Not Vitious, but pure Vice it ſelf, I ſware.

lg.head: Epig. XV. De Colono.
lg.l: Heredes nolite brevem ſepelire colonum.
Nam terra eſt illi quantulacunque gravis.

lg.head: Epig. LXVIII. In Maronem.
lg.l: Nil mihi das vivus: dicis poſt fata daturum.
Si non es ſtultus, ſcis Maro quid cupiam.

lg.head: Epig. LXIX. Ad Mathonem.
lg.l: Parva rogas magnos: ſed non haec quoque magui.
Ut pudeat leviùs te Matho, magna roga.

lg.head: Epig. LXXXIV. Ad Soſibianum.
lg.l: Nemo habitat gratis, niſi dives & orbus apud te.
Nemo domum pluris, Soſibiane, locat.

lg.head: Epig. XCIII. In Zoilum:
lg.l: Mentitur, qui te vitioſum, Zoiles, dixit.
Non vitioſus homo es, Zoile, ſed vitium.

lg.head: Epig. VII. Of Ligia.
lg.l: If Ligia equal years and hairs doth hold,
Now Gran-dame Ligia's almoſt three year old.

lg.head: Epig. X. Of Africanus.
lg.l: Though he's worth Thouſands, yet his fingers itch;
All are ſtill poor, though many be too rich.

lg.head: Epig. XIII. To Auctus.
lg.l: Anger, rich men do count a gain: they live
At leſs expence of purſe to hate, then give.

lg.head: Epig. XLVII. Upon a divers-humour'd man.
lg.l: Th'art merry, ſad, eaſre, and hard to pleaſe;
Nor with, nor from thee can I live at eaſe.

lg.head: Epig. LI. Of Fabullus.
lg.l: Wonder no more that Fabull's cheated ſo;
An honeſt man is ſimply honeſt, know.

lg.head: Epig. LIV. Upon Zoilus.
lg.l: Red hair, black mouth, badger legs, blind, I ſee;
Be, Zoilus, good, and the worlds wonder be.

lg.head: Epig. CII. To Mattus.
lg.l: He who denyes himſelf at home, you ſee,
Mattus, doth ſay, I am aſleep to thee.

lg.head: Epig. VII. De Ligeia.
lg.l: Toto vertice quot gerit capillos,
Annos ſi tot habet Ligeia, trima eſt.

lg.head: Epig. X. De Africano.
lg.l: Habet Africanus millies, tamen captat;
Fortuna multis dat nimis, ſatis nulli.

lg.head: Epig. XIII. Ad Auctum.
lg.l: Genus, Aucte, lucri divites habent iram;
Odiſſe quàm donare vilius conſtat.

lg.head: Epig. XLVII. In habentem varios mores,
lg.l: Difficilis, facilis, jucundus, acerbus es idem:
Nec tecum poſſum vivere, nec ſine te.

lg.head: Epig. LI. De Fabullo.
lg.l: Tam ſaepe noſtrum deeipi Fabullum, quid
Miraris Aule? ſemper bonus homo tiro eſt.

lg.head: Epig. LIV. In Zoilum.
lg.l: Crine ruber, niger ore, brevis pede, lumine laeſus.
Rem magnam praeſtas, Zoile, ſi bonus es.

lg.head: Epig. CII. Ad Martum.
lg.l: Qui negat eſſe domi ſe, tunc cùm limina pulſas.
Quid dicat, neſcis? dormio, Matte, tibi.

lg.head: Epig. IV. Frankincenſe.
lg.l: Send perfum'd prayers to Jove, that Caeſar may
Long rule on earth, e're he heaven's ſcepter ſway.

lg.head: Epig. XVIII. Leeks.
lg.l: When you Tarentine, Leeks eat, ſhun offence,
With lips cloſe ſeal'd a breathleſs kiſs diſpence.

lg.head: Epig. XXII. Reiſins in the ſun.
lg.l: Fit nor for cup, nor Bacchus; I will be
Nectar, although not Potable, to thee.

lg.head: Epig. XXXIX. A Goat.
lg.l: You once did Bacchus wound; this death you have,
O wanton Goat, for the then wound you gave.

lg.head: Epig. LIII. A Turtle-Dove
lg.l: Lettuce farewell; fat Turtles give to me;
And poynant hunger the beſt ſawce will be.

lg.head: Epig. LIX. A Dormouſe.
lg.l: Sleeping all Winter I'm moſt fat; no food,
But a full meal of ſleep doth work this good.

lg.head: Epig. LX. A Rabit.
lg.l: You a ſmall Burrough working, do defign
Captains great Cities how to undermine.

lg.head: Epig. LXII. On a cramn'd Hen.
lg.l: The Hen grows fat, with darkneſs fed and dough;
The very gut doth now ingenious grow.

lg.head: Epig. LXXVI. A wilde Partridge.
lg.l: I a wilde Partridge am; what difference? nought,
But that the tame one is the dearer bought.

lg.head: Epig. LXXXVII. The Purple fiſh.
lg.l: O moſt ungratefull man, not only you
Do dye with me; but likewiſe eat me too.

lg.head: Epig. XCIV. The Does.
lg.l: The Tusk, the Boar; Harts, horns defend, to all
We naked Does, prey undefended, fall.

lg.head: Epig. CXXII. Vineger.
lg.l: Aegyptian Vineger deſpiſe not thou:
When it was Wine, 'twas far more vile chan now.

lg.head: Epig. CXXV. Tarentine wine.
lg.l: Happy, and fam'd Aulon, in wool, and wine,
The fleece take thou, give me the richer Vine.

lg.head: Epig. CXXVII. A Coronet of Roſes to Caeſar.
lg.l: Winter a Roſe preſents unto thy Throne;
Once 'twas the Springs, but now 'tis Caeſars grown.

lg.head: Epig. IV. Thus.
lg.l: Serus ut aethereae Germanicus imperet aulae,
Utque diu terris, da pia thura Jovi.

lg.head: Epig. XVIII. Porri ſectivi.
lg.l: Fila Tarentini graviter redolentia porri
Ediſti quoties, oſcula clauſa dato.

lg.head: Epig. XXII. Uva duracina.
lg.l: Non habilis cyathis, & inutilis uva Lyaeo:
Sed non potanti me, tibi Nectar ero.

lg.head: Epig. XXXIX. Hoedo.
lg.l: Laſcivum pecus, & viridi non utile Baccho
Det poenas: nocuit jam tenet ille deo.

lg.head: Epig. LIII. Turtur.
lg.l: Dum pinguis mibi turtur erit: lactuca valebis,
Et cochleas tibi habe; perdere nolo famem.

lg.head: Epig. LIX. Glires.
lg.l: Tota mihi dormitur byems, & pinguior illo
Tempore ſum, quo me nil niſi ſomnus alit.

lg.head: Epig. LX. Cuniculus.
lg.l: Gaudet in effoſſis habitare cuniculus antris:
Monſtravit tacitas hoſtibus ille vias.

lg.head: Epig. LXII. Gallina altilis.
lg.l: Paſcitur & dulci facilis gallina farinâ,
Paſcitur & tenebris; ingenìoſa gula eſt.

lg.head: Epig. LXXVI. Ruſticula.
lg.l: Ruſtica ſum, an perdix, quid refert ſi ſapor idem eſt?
Carior eſt perdix: ſic ſapit illa magis.

lg.head: Epig. LXXXVII. Murices.
lg.l: Sanguine de noſtro tinctas ingrate lacernas
Induis, &, non eſt hoc ſatis, eſca ſumus.

lg.head: Epig. XCIV. Damae.
lg.l: Dente timentur api; defendunt cornua cervos:
Imbelles damae, quid niſi praeda ſumus?

lg.head: Epig. CXXII. Acetum.
lg.l: Amphora Niliaci non ſit tibi vilit aceti:
Eſſet cùm vinum, vilior illa fuit.

lg.head: Epig. CXXV. Tarentinum.
lg.l: Nobilis & lanis, & felix vitibus Aulon
Det pretioſa tibi vellera, vina mihi.

lg.head: Epig. CXXVII. Corona Roſea.
lg.l: Dat feſtinata Caeſar tibi bruma coronas,
Quondam veris erant, nunc tua facta roſa eſt.

lg.head: Epig. XII. An Ivory Cabinet.
lg.l: Theſe Ivory Tills ſhould nought contain but Gold,
And more vile wood ſhould baſer ſilver hold.

lg.head: Epig. XVI. A Caſting box.
lg.l: The cogging hand may ſlur a Dye; with me
No ſlight prevails, only your hopes are free.

lg.head: Epig. XXXIV. A Sithe made of a Sword.
lg.l: Me to a better Trade calme Peace doth change,
I, in the Camp did ſerve, do in the Scange.

lg.head: Epig. XLIV. A Wooden Candleſtick.
lg.l: Unleſs you mind, and mend the light, you'l ſee
The Candleſtick it ſelf will Candle be.

lg.head: Epig. LXXIII. A Parret.
lg.l: To complement my Maſter teacheth me;
But I by nature am taught loyalty.

lg.head: Epig. LXXV. A Nightingale.
lg.l: Wrong'd Philomel, while woman, mute was ſhe;
But ſince a bird, ſings her own Eligy.

lg.head: Epig. LXXVI. A Pie.
lg.l: Did you nor ſee, (ſuch a true voyce I fain)
Thinking me man, you would Salute again.

lg.head: Epig. LXXXIX. A Citron-table.
lg.l: Atlas this Citron-table ſends to thee:
Should he give gold, the gift would viler be.

lg.head: Epig. CXI. Chryſtal-glaſſes.
lg.l: You Chryſtal break, for fear of breaking it:
Careleſs and carefull hands like fault commit.

lg.head: Epig. CXXXIII. A Granada Cloak.
lg.l: I'me as I ſeem; not any dyer gave,
But nature dyed this colour that I have.

lg.head: Epig. CXLVII. A Rugge.
lg.l: Warm purple Ruggs without, what profit theſe,
If an old Wife within doth make thee freeze?

lg.head: Epig. CLXII. Hay.
lg.l: Sruff thy cheap Tick with hay, pale care will fly;
She never doth upon a hard bed ly.

lg.head: Epig. CLXXVII. Corinthian Hercules.
lg.l: See how the Child doth the two Serpents tear,
And ſqueeze out life; Hydra even now may fear.

lg.head: Epig. CLXXX. The picture of Europa.
lg.l: Great Father of the gods, a Bull then thou
Should'ſt be, when Iö was transform'd a Cow.

lg.head: Epig. CLXXXI. Leander in Marble.
lg.l: Thus bold Leander ſpake to the ſwel'd wave;
Spare me till I return, be then my grave.

lg.head: Epig. CXC. Livy in Parchment.
lg.l: In a ſmall Parchment ſee great Livy roll'd;
Whom all my Study is too ſmall to hold.

lg.head: Epig. CXCIV. Lucan.
lg.l: There ſome be ſay I do not poetize:
But he who ſells me finds it otherwiſe.

lg.head: Epig. CXCVII. A little Mule.
lg.l: You need not fear a fall from the low Mule;
You almoſt higher ſit when earth's your ſtool.

lg.head: Epig. CCVIII. A Notary.
lg.l: This ſwifter hand doth the ſwift words out-run,
Before the Tongue hath ſpoke, the hand hath done.

lg.head: Epig. CCX. A Fool.
lg.l: A modeſt Folly may for wiſdome go;
And he's leſs wife that would ſeem more than ſo.

lg.head: Epig. CCXI. A Ram's bead.
lg.l: You the Phryxean beaſt do kill; yet he
Diſrob'd himſelf to dreſs ungratefull thee.

lg.head: Epig. CCXII. A Dwarf.
lg.l: Whom for his Head you Hector think, you'l call
Hector's young ſon, when you perceive how tall.

lg.head: Epig. CCXVII. On an Ordinary.
lg.l: Your Ordinary and number name; what is't?
Not a word more; your Supper's dreſt and diſht.

lg.head: Epig. CCXX. A cook.
lg.l: A Cook ſhould double one ſence have; for he
Should taſter for himſelf and maſter be.

lg.head: Epig. XII. Loculi eborei.
lg.l: Hos niſi de flava loculos implere monetâ
Non decet; argentum vilia ligna ferant.

lg.head: Epig. XVI. Turricula.
lg.l: Quae ſcit compoſitos manus improba mittere talos,
Si per me miſit, nil niſi vota facit.

lg.head: Epig. XXXIV. Falx ex enſe.
lg.l: Pax me certa ducis placidos curvavit in uſus.
Agricolae nune ſum, militis ante ſui.

lg.head: Epig. XLIV. Candelabrum ligneum.
lg.l: Eſſe vides lign •• um: ſerves niſi lumina ſiet
De candetabro magna lucerna tibi.

lg.head: Epig. LXXIII. Pſittacus.
lg.l: Pſittacus à vobis aliorum nomina diſcam:
Hoc didici per me dicere, Caeſar, ave.

lg.head: Epig. LXXVI. Pica.
lg.l: Pica loquax certa dominum te voce ſaluto:
Si me non videas, eſſe negabis avem.

lg.head: Epig. LXXXIX. Menſa citrea.
lg.l: Accipe felices Atlantica munera ſylvas:
Aurea qui dederit dona, minora dabit.

lg.head: Epig. CXI. Chryſtallina.
lg.l: Frangere dum metuis, frangis chryſtallina: peccant
Securae nimium, ſolicitaeque manus.

lg.head: Epig. CXXXIII. Lacernae Baeticae.
lg.l: Non eſt lana mihi mendax, nec mutor aëno:
Si placeant Tyriae, me mea tinxit ovis.

lg.head: CXLVII. Cubicularia gauſapina.
lg.l: Stragula purpureis lucent villoſa tapetis;
Quid prodeſt, ſi te congelat uxor anus?

lg.head: Epig. CLXII. Foenum.
lg.l: Fraudata tumeat facilis tibi culcita pluma;
Non venit ad duros pallidá cura toros.

lg.head: Epig. CLXXVII. Hercules Corinthius.
lg.l: Elidit geminos infans, nec reſpicit angues;
Jam poterat teneras hydra timere manus.

lg.head: Epig. CLXXX. Europa picta.
lg.l: Mutari melius tauro pater optime divûm
Tunc poteras, Iô cum tibi vacca fuit.

lg.head: Epig. CLXXXI. Leander marmoreus.
lg.l: Clamabat tumidis audax Leander in undis,
Mergite me fluctus, cùm rediturus ero.

lg.head: Epig. CXC. Livius in membranis.
lg.l: Pellibus exiguis arctatur Livius ingens,
Quem mea non totum bibliotheca capit.

lg.head: Epig. CXCVI. Lucan.
lg.l: Sunt quidam, qui me dicunt non eſſe Poetam:
Sed qui me vendit bibliopola, putat.

lg.head: Epig. CXCVII. Mulae pomiliae.
lg.l: His tibi de mulis non eſt metuanda ruina:
Altiùs in terra paene ſedere ſoles.

lg.head: Epig. CCVIII. Notarius.
lg.l: Currant verba licet manus eſt velocior illis:
Nondum lingua ſuum, dextra perigit opus.

lg.head: Epig. CCX. Morio.
lg.l: Non mendax ſtupor eſt, nec ſingitur arte doloſa
Quiſquls plus juſto non ſapit, ille ſapit.

lg.head: Epig. CCXI. Caput arietinum.
lg.l: Mollia Phryxei ſecuiſti colla mariti,
Hoc meruit, tunicam qui tibi ſaepe dedit.

lg.head: Epig. CCXII. Pumilio.
lg.l: Si ſolum spectes hominis caput, Hectora credes:
Si ſtantem videas. Aſtyanacta plures.

lg.head: Epig. CCXVII. Obſonator.
lg.l: Dic quotus, & quanti cupias coenare, nec unum
Addideris verbum: coena parata tibi eſt.

lg.head: Epig. CCXX. Coquus.
lg.l: Non ſatis eſt ars ſola coquo, ſervire palato:

Nam
que coquus domini debet habere gulam.

div.head: THE CHOICEST DISTICKS Of all the Chief LATINE POETS That have writ in theſe Two laſt CENTURIES.

lg.head: Upon the Seal of a Love-letter.
lg.l: OPening the Wax, Husbandmen Honey find;
The ſame ſhall you, having this Wax disjoy'nd.

lg.head: The Epitaph of the moſt upright Senator, Carterius.
lg.l: Friend, read, and wonder at this Obſequy;
For here the ſtrange thing, a good man doth ly.

lg.head: In ceram quâ obſignantur literae amatoriae.
lg.l: AGricolae reſerant ceras, & mella leguntur;

Hanc reſera ceram, tu quo
que mella leges.

lg.head: Epitaphium Carterii Senatoris integerrimi.
lg.l: Qui legis hunc titulum tumuli, miraberis, hospes:
Res ſimilis monſtri, vir bonus hic ſitus eſt.

lg.head: Upon a certain Encomiaſt of Aſſes.
lg.l: Why praiſe you Aſſes, alwaies erring thus?
Doſt thou not know? know thy ſelf, Ponticus.

lg.head: On Zoilus.
lg.l: My Book to you, O Zoilus, ſeems too ſmall:
I only wiſh it would ſeem ſo to all.

lg.head: Upon Drunkards.
lg.l: You often ask to ſee a drunken man:
Such a one, Naevolus you nowhere can.

lg.head: M. Brutus Felo de ſe.
lg.l: I, under Caeſar might his treaſure uſe,
But then a Lord, free death did rather chooſe.

lg.head: Xenophon bearing in his left hnnd a Pen, and in his right a Sword.
lg.l: Mars, and the Muſes ſerving, Barbarous men
By th' Sword I vanquiſh, Language by the Pen.

lg.head: In quendam aſinorum Encomiaſten.
lg.l: Dum laudas aſinos, toties cur, Pontice, peccas?
Nempe tibi ignotum 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 erat.

lg.head: In Zoilum.
lg.l: Brevem Zoile dicis huuc libellum:
O ſi poſſit idem omnibus videri!

lg.head: In Ebrioſos.
lg.l: Quaeris quis ſit homo ebrioſus? at qui
Nullus eſt homo, Naevole, ebrioſus.
Divitiis uti licuit cum Caeſare partis;
Ferre necem poſſum, non potui dominum.

lg.head: Xenophon laevâ calamum, dextrâ gladium geſtans.
lg.l: Quid Marti, & Muſis, Xenophon? ſic vlcimus olim
Barbariem gladio, barbariem calamo.

lg.head: Upon certain Writers of this Age.
lg.l: Why thus obſcure d'ee write? or make a clue
To th' Paper Labyrinth, or you nothing do.

lg.head: Of P. Felix.
lg.l: Why Felix doth not wed d'ee ask? the ſame
When he ſhall do, he muſt divorce his name.

lg.head: In quoſdam hujus aetatis ſcriptores.
lg.l: Quid juvat obſcuris iuvolvere ſcripta latebris?
Ni pateant animi ſenſa, tacere potes.

lg.head: De P. Felice.
lg.l: Quaritis, uxorem fugiat cur ducere Felix?
Hoc ſine jacturâ nominis ille nequit.

lg.head: Of a rich unlearned man.
lg.l: The Cynick of a rich Dunce ſaid, I ſee
Sheep Golden-fleec'd, the Fables's true, quoth he.

lg.head: In divitem indoctum.
lg.l: Videt ut indoctum Cynicus, cui purpura veſtis;
Aurato video vellere dixit, ovem.

lg.head: On a ball'd-man.
lg.l: I know thee not, yet praiſe thy hair, they hate
And ſcorn to dwell on ſuch a naſty pate.

lg.head: The Epitaph of Turnebus.
lg.l: Here lyes Turnebus: ask whoſe he? then know
Y'are groſſy ignorant, and be ever ſo.

lg.head: In Calvum.
lg.l: Calve mihi, tecum nihil eſt, ſed laudo capillos
Iſtud quòd tetrum deſeruere caput.

lg.head: Turnebi Epitaphium incerto authore.
lg.l: Turnebus jacet hîc: quis ſit ſi quaerere pergis,
Jam dignus es qui neſcias.

lg.head: On a Covetous man's death,
lg.l: The Covetous man, whoſe Life's a living death,
Grieves not to dy, but gratis loſe his breath.

lg.head: On the Picture of Menodus.
lg.l: Menodot's Picture Diodore did Lim,
'Twas live like to any one but him.

lg.head: Avari mors.
lg.l: Non gemit ob mortem, cui vita ſimillima morti:
Sed quòd ſit gratis mors morienda dolet.

lg.head: Laeonidae, è Graeco.
lg.l: Menodoti effigiem pinxit Diodorus, at illa eſt
Menodoto excepto cuilibet aſſimilis.

lg.head: The ſaying of Crates the Mileſian.
lg.l: Would'ſt thou what's rare, and un-accuſtomed ſee?
There's nought ſo rare as long-liv'd Tyranny.

lg.head: Vox Cratetis Mileſii.
lg.l: Quaeris difficile invenire quid ſit?
O quàm difficile eſt ſenem tyrannum!

lg.head: Venus cut in marble.
lg.l: The Poets Venus call a Whore; I ſee
Not why; yet know, this is all Chaſtity.

lg.head: Venus marmorea.
lg.l: Neſcio cur Venerem meretricem carmina dicant;
Hoc ſcio quòd nihil hac caſtius eſſe poteſt.

lg.head: A Lyer's reward.
lg.l: What doth a Lyer get by being ſo?
This, even his Truth for Truth ſhall never go.

lg.head: On Zozimus.
lg.l: Zozimus ſayes his Tongue's like Mercury:
Not ſo good Zozimus; your fingers be.

lg.head: On the Tombe of Archilochus, out of Greek.
lg.l: Paſs this Tomb, Reader, ſoftly as you can:
Waſpiſh Iambicks leaſt you raiſe again.

lg.head: On Zoilus.
lg.l: At all things Zoilus ſnaps and hath a fling:
He's ſordid, Zoilus, ſnaps at every thing.

lg.head: Mendacii merces.
lg.l: Mendacio quid vanus acquirit ſibi?
Ut vera dicens impetret numquam fidem.

lg.head: In Zozimum.
lg.l: Mercurio ſimilem dicis te, Zozime, linguâ:
Fallit te ratio, Zozime; die manibus.

lg.head: In tumulum Archilochi, è Graeco.
lg.l: Hoc ne crabrones tumulo irritentur humati,
Quàm potes hinc tacitè, quaeſo, viator abi.

lg.head: In Zoilum.
lg.l: Qui nihil ipſe facis, cur omnia, Zoile mordes?
Omnia qui mordet, Zoile, ſordidus eſt.

lg.head: On a certain man.
lg.l: Aeolus Cheek, face Son of Semele,
Vulcan's pace; Strange! three Gods in one man ſee.

lg.head: On too delicate a Feaſt-maker.
lg.l: And why theſe Kickſhaws? Puff-paſt is not it
Which I deſire: diſh me an Appetite.

lg.head: The Image of Bacchus on a Fountain.
lg.l: Unhappy Mid-wife, fire had almoſt proved
My death, unborn, ſince I have Fountains lov'd.

lg.head: In quendam.
lg.l: Mulciber inceſſu, capite Aeolus, ore Lydus,
Tres uno duos corpore ſolus habes.

lg.head: In Convivatorem nimi ùm prolixium.
lg.l: Quonam ſcriblitas, quonam iſta ſophiſmata ponis?
Vis benè convivas paſcere? pone famem.

lg.head: Bacchus fonti impoſitus.
lg.l: Nondum natus cram, cum me propè perdidit ignis:
Ex illo ſontes tempore Bacchus amo.

lg.head: To the Phyſicians.
lg.l: Your pains are free to me; the gift is brave:
But yet not worth the hazard of a grave.

lg.head: Upon Otho.
lg.l: Who, Otho, ſayes, lyes alwaies, doth no leſs;
Otho himſelf a Lyer doth confeſs.

lg.head: On Quintus.
lg.l: Evil to do when Quintus you do fear,
You do no good while you thus doubtfull are.

lg.head: Upon Marcus.
lg.l: Who, Marcus, ſayes, gives words, doth do him wrong;
Marcus no words doth give, he ſells his tongue.

lg.head: A Staff.
lg.l: What Nature hath deny'd eyes, ears, and mind;
Though ſenceleſs, is a conduct to the Blind.

lg.head: On a bad Author of Faſting.
lg.l: So hungerly you do for Faſting plead,
Though faſting, I am cloid when you I read.

lg.head: Of Harpalus.
lg.l: The Poor, his Heir, makes Harpalus; that he
Who ſhould be ſo, might weep unfeinedly.

lg.head: Myron's Cow.
lg.l: Herdſman, and herd, nay Mycon I deceive;
And Jove turn'd Bull, for me would heaven leave.

lg.head: To Candidus.
lg.l: Me, ſick you viſit, not when well I be:
O mayſt thou never, if thus, viſit me.

lg.head: To Nicholas Paſchaſius.
lg.l: So with the Gods act as if man did hear,
And ſo with Man as if the Gods were there.

lg.head: To Paulus.
lg.l: Following great men you your ſelf great eſteem;
Young Pages and ſmall Dwarfs do follow them.

lg.head: An Epitaph upon a Baſtard.
lg.l: Who Urne inclos'd lyes here, doſt ask his name?
I, Reader, know not, nor did he the ſame.

lg.head: Ad medicos.
lg.l: Gratuitas operas mibi qui promittitis aegro,
Parcite; non tanti eſt aeger ut eſſe velim.

lg.head: In Othonem
lg.l: Mentitur quiſquis mentiri ſemper Othonem
Dicit; mendacem ſe profitetur Otho.

lg.head: In Quintum.
lg.l: Dum dubius fluit hâc aut illâc, dum timet anceps
Ne malè quid faciat, nil benè Quintus agit.

lg.head: In Marcum.
lg.l: Errat, qui Marcum credit dare verba clienti;
Marcus verba ſolet vendere, nulla dare.

lg.head: Baculus.
lg.l: Cui natura ocalos, 'aures, animamque negavit,

Hic tamen eſt coeco dux
que redux
que viae.

lg.head: In malum jejuniorum ſcriptorem.
lg.l: Tam pia jejunè tractas jejunia, ut illa
Dum lego jejunus, ſum ſatiatus ego.

lg.head: De Harpalo.
lg.l: Omnia pauperibus moriens dedit Harpalus, haeres
Ut ſe non fictus exprimat in lachrymas.

lg.head: Bucula Myronis.
lg.l: Fallo gregem, fallo paſtorem, fallo Myronem:
Induet & pro me Jupiter ipſe bovem.

lg.head: Ad Candidum.
lg.l: Aegrotum viſis, ſanum me viſere ceſſas:
O utinam uunquam, Candide, me videas.

lg.head: Ad Nicholaum Paſchaſium filium.
lg.l: Sic age cum ſuperis quaſi te plebs audiat omnis;
Sic age cum populo, dit quaſi te videant.

lg.head: Ad Paulum.
lg.l: Quòd ſequeris reges, magnus tibi, Paule, videris;
Qui magnos ſequitur, Paule, puſillus homo eſt.

lg.head: Cujuſdam Anonymi, vel (ſi mavis) ſpurii Epitaphium.
lg.l: Quaeris quis jacet hac, viator, urnâ?
Nomen neſcio, neſciebat ipſe.

lg.head: A Womans nature.
lg.l: Women ſweet evils are, and twice good thoſe;
Both in their Wedding, and their winding cloths.

lg.head: Mulieris Natura.
lg.l: Foemina dulce malum, horis opportuna du abus,
Cum jacet in thalamo, cum jacet in tumulo.

lg.head: On the Title of a certain Book.
lg.l: A Book of Toyes, your Book, you, Paulus, call,
The Title of the Piece is beſt of all.

lg.head: The Epitaph of a Dogg.
lg.l: The Lover I let paſſe, the Thief did ſeize:
So I both Maſter did, and Miſtreſs pleaſe.

lg.head: In libri cujuſdam titulum.
lg.l: Paule, tuum inſcribis nugarum nomine librum,
In toto libro nil melius titulo.

lg.head: Epitaphium Canis.
lg.l: Latratu ſures excepi, mutus amanti:
Sic placui domino, ſic placui dominae.

lg.head: On a Covetous man.
lg.l: Dying Avarus weeps, not to lament
His death, but coin in Cake, and Coffin ſpent.

lg.head: To his Father.
lg.l: Father, you ſay my Fancie's cold and low:
The Water-Poets fancy's alwayes ſo.

lg.head: In avarum.
lg.l: Dum moritur, lacrymat, non quòd moriatur avarus,
Sed loculum tanti quod ſibi nollet emi.

lg.head: Ad Patrem.
lg.l: Frigida noſtra pater dixiſti carmina: ſanè
Frigent quae fecit carmina potor aquae.

lg.head: To Apelles.
lg.l: Why paint you Venus Water-born? when ſhe
Born of hot luſtfull Wine ſhould rather be.

lg.head: Of Love and Bees.
lg.l: Thus Love and Bees agree: both honey bear
And ſting: both love the ſound of Chink to hear.

lg.head: Ad Apellem.
lg.l: Emerſam ex undis Venerem cur pingis Apelles?
Spumifero natam tu mage pinge mero.

lg.head: De amore & apibus.
lg.l: Conveniunt & apes & amor: nam spicula melle

Mixta gerunt: aeris gaudet uter
que ſono.

lg.head: The power of wine.
lg.l: Bacchus both ſtrength doth adde, and yet abate.
When ſoberly; when drunk immoderate.

lg.head: To Cantulus.
lg.l: A Wife you took deform'd, yet rich 'tis ſaid:
By th' Fingers, Cantulus, not eyes you wed.

lg.head: Bacchi vis.
lg.l: Extenuat Bacchus vires, & roborat idem;
Si ſuerit nimius; ſi fuerit modicus.

lg.head: Cantulo.
lg.l: Duxiſti uxorem deformem, ſed locupletem;
Duxiſti digitis, Cantule, non oculis.

lg.head: Of Fabius.
lg.l: Fabius is moſt believed, yet moſt doth lye;
His words not taken, but Security.

lg.head: Of Titus.
lg.l: Titus was tame when ſingle; yet ſince he
Was yoak'd in Wedlock, butts moſt cruelly.

lg.head: Of Celſus.
lg.l: In ſelf-love Celſus burns; he, Candidus,
Is happy man, he hath no Rival thus.

lg.head: Paris.
lg.l: Judge, Firebrand, Gueſt, mad, fatal, perjured,
I, Venus, Ilium, Helen, praiſe, fire, wed.

lg.head: Aeneas.
lg.l: I Valour have, and Piety: and gain
By them in Italy and Heaven to reign.

lg.head: Fabius Maxim • s.
lg.l: Let others do great things, Cunctator, I
Will nothing do, yet get the Victory.

lg.head: Pompeius.
lg.l: Envy not Caeſar's fortune, it declares
Unhappy you, him guilly in the wars.

lg.head: In Fabium.
lg.l: Nulli quàm Fabio tota plus creditur urbe;
Mendacine adeo? quomodo? pignora dat.

lg.head: De Tito.
lg.l: Antea mitis erat Titus; at nunc conjuge ducta,
Occurſare Tito, cornuferit ille, caveto.

lg.head: De Celſo.
lg.l: Ardet amore ſui Cel ſus: nonne ille beatus?
Rivalem nullum, Candide, Celſus habet.

lg.head: Paris.
lg.l: Judex, fax, hoſpes, maleſanus, acerba, ſcele ſtus,
Cyprida, Trojam, Helenam, laudo, cremo, rapio.

lg.head: Aeneas.
lg.l: Sum pius & fortis: duplex duo praemia virtus;
Italiae haec regnum dat mihi, at illa polum.

lg.head: Fabius Maximus.
lg.l: Res gerat egregias alius; proprium hoc mihi, quòd rem
Romanam Fabius ſervo gerendo nihil.

lg.head: Pompeius.
lg.l: Ne nimiùm invideas fortunae Caeſaris; acti
Eſtis in Aemathia, tu miſer, ille nocens.

lg.head: An unlearned Nobleman.
lg.l: Who diſagree in Cloaths, agree in this;
The Nobleman and Clown like learned is.

lg.head: Of the fear of death.
lg.l: The fear of death is worſe than death; we may
Cuntemn, we cannot ſhun the fatal day.

lg.head: Nobilis imperitus.
lg.l: Suat diſcolores veſtibus, plebs, nobiles;

Sed concolores ſunt utri
que moribus.

lg.head: De timore mortis.
lg.l: Formido mortis morte pejor; non potes
Vitare mortem, ſed potes contemnere.

lg.head: To Charles Borgia.
lg.l: My Muſe ne're ſeeing thy Father, wept; but ſhe,
I've ſeen him ſaid, and ceas'd, when ſhe ſaw thee.

lg.head: Ad Carolum Borgiam Ducem Gaudiae.
lg.l: Flebat Muſa tuam ſe non vidiſſe parentem;
Cum te reſpexit; vidi, ait, & tacuit.

lg.head: A Pome-Citterne.
lg.l: The tart ſweet taſt theſe Venus Aples ſpeak;
Thus Love a bitter ſweet is ſtiled by th' Greek.

lg.head: An Almond tree.
lg.l: Why art thou ripe ſo early in the year?
I hate too early ripeneſs anywhere.

lg.head: An Oak.
lg.l: I once for fruit was us'd, for ſhade now be:
Eyen thus I ſtill am Jove's officious tree.

lg.head: Malus medica.
lg.l: Aurea ſunt Veneris poma haec; jucundus amator
Indicat; eſt Graecis ſic 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 amor.

lg.head: Amigdalus.
lg.l: Cur properans foliis praemiltis, Amigdale, flores?
Odi pupillos praecocis ingenii.

lg.head: Quercus.
lg.l: Glande aluit veteres, ſold nunc proficit umbrâ:

Sic quo
que ſic arbor officioſa Jovis.

lg.head: To the Painter of Coelia.
lg.l: Deface this Piece; leaſt with a double fire
We burn; Picture and Life both flames inſpire.

lg.head: Ad pictorem de imagine Coeliae.
lg.l: Dele opus hoc, pictor; duplici ne Coelia flammâ
Nos urat: picta & viva dat ore faces.

lg.head: Of Doctor Soſylus.
lg.l: The Butcher Soſylus a Quack is made:
Nor wonder; he but name hath chang'd, not Trade.

lg.head: De Soſylo Medico.
lg.l: De lanio medicus fit Soſylus: haud nova res est;
Fecit enim lanius, quod facit & medicus.

lg.head: Of a beauteous Boy
lg.l: Seeing a fair dead Boy, kind Venus ſaid,
Ah me! ſuch my Adonis was when dead.

lg.head: De puero formoſo.
lg.l: Exanimum Paphie puerum miſerata feretro:
Eheu! talis, ait, noſter Adonis erat.

lg.head: To Flaccus.
lg.l: Rejoyce, you'r old and honeſt, Flaccus; you
Being age-bound, what you ſhould not, cannot do.

lg.head: To Maurus.
lg.l: Pardon thy ſuppliant Foe; think, Maurus, you
Puniſh enough, if able ſo to do.

lg.head: An envious Man's puniſhment.
lg.l: Let Zoilus carp; yet, Titus, I'me content;
An envious mind is a ſelf-puniſhment.

lg.head: To Linus.
lg.l: The Sickneſs you would ſhun, the Plague you fear:
Change your Conditions, Linus, not the air.

lg.head: Ad Flaccum.
lg.l: Immenſas tremulae grates age, Flacce, ſenectae,
Nam quod dubueras nec voluiſſe, nequis.

lg.head: Ad Maurum.
lg.l: Maure, tuas jacet ante fores, & ſupplicat hoſtis:
Paenarum ulcijci poſſe, ſat eſſe puta.

lg.head: Invidus poena ſui.
lg.l: Mordenti mirare meos me parcere verſus?
Invida ſat gravis eſt mens, Tite, poena ſui.

lg.head: Ad Linum.
lg.l: St quibus obrueris mens eſt explodere peflies,
Eſt opus eſſe alium te, Line, non alibi.

lg.head: To an old man uſing a ſtaff.
lg.l: And why this Staff? your legs, alone I know,
Sufficient are Death's Pilgrimage to go.

lg.head: A rule to live and dye well.
lg.l: Learn well to live, ſo death will happy be:
Learn well to dye, ſo you'l live happily.

lg.head: Niobe.
lg.l: The Carver makes not what the gods did do;
Stone is the Life, and Stone th' Effigies too.

lg.head: Of the ſame.
lg.l: The Gods from life transform'd me Stone in vain:
Praxiteles doth give me life again.

lg.head: Ad ſenem baculo utentem.
lg.l: Quid baculo moliris iter, quid te magis urges
Ad mortem gemino nou ſatis ire pede?

lg.head: Inſtructio ad mortem.
lg.l: Ut tibi mors felix contingat, vivere diſce:
Ut felix poſſis vivere, diſce mori.

lg.head: Niobe.
lg.l: Qualis eram me talem opifex effinxit, & olim
Me lapidem factam, nune lapidem eſſe vides.

lg.head: In candem,
lg.l: Vivam o'im in lapidem verterunt numina: ſed me
Praxiteles vivam reddidit ex lapide.

lg.head: To Gaurus the Grammarian.
lg.l: Male, Female, Neuter born? ſure, Gaurus, you
By th' Rule of Grammer get your children too.

lg.head: Gauro Grammatico.
lg.l: Tres nati ſunt, Gaure, tibi, mas, faemina, neutrum:
Gratulor, eſt ſoboles congrua Grammatico.

lg.head: Of Love.
lg.l: Fire in the Ice, Ice in the Fire, I prove:
How came theſe Evils ask you? know I love.

lg.head: De ſuo amore.
lg.l:
Exuror glacie in media, dum
que uror, in igne
Algeo: cur patior haec mala quaeris? amo?

lg.head: A Marigold.
lg.l: Now to the ſet, now to the riſe, I turn;
Have I not ſence? in the Sun's love I burn.

lg.head: A Lark in a Cage.
lg.l: Nought's worſe than Bonds: releaſe me Wretch and I
Will ſinging raiſe your prayſe unto the sky.

lg.head: Soliſequa.
lg.l: Vertor ad occaſum, rurſus convertor ad ortum.
Solis amoradios; an mihi ſenſus ineſt?

lg.head: Alauda in caveâ.
lg.l: Asperius nibil eſt vinclis, & carcerie antro:
Solvite me miſeram, ſolvite, dulce canam.

lg.head: Of Zeuxis and Parrhaſius.
lg.l: Zeuxis the Fowles, Parrhaſius Zeuxis can
Deceive: this cheats the Bird, but he the Man.

lg.head: The Elephant.
lg.l: Who can deny immortal Deities?
When very beaſts acknowledge ſuch as theſe.

lg.head: De certamine Zeuxis & Parrhaſii.
lg.l: Fallit aves Zeuxis, Zeuxis deluditur arte
Parrhaſii, volucres hic capit, ille virum.

lg.head: Elephas.
lg.l: Quis tollet ſuperos? Quis numina ſancta negabit?
Cum fera perpetuos ſentiat eſſe Deos.

lg.head: Of Dido.
lg.l: Unhappy Dido ſtill with croſs Fate wed:
When that dyed ſlying, dying when you fled.

lg.head: De Didone.
lg.l: Infelix Dido nulli bene nupta marito:
Hoc pereunte fugis, hoc fugiente peris.

div.head: Marius Bettinus.
Of the Baptiſt in the Wilderneſs.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.l: Thee, Cave-inhabitant, what ſhall I call?

sp.speaker: Bapt.
sp.l: Doſt thou not hear? the Cave doth tell; a Call.

lg.head: Upon Judas.
lg.l: If Hail bring death, what may an evil word?
If thus thy kiſs doth wound, how would thy Sword?

lg.head: Upon Chriſts birth-night.

epigraph.q: The night ſhineth as the day, &c.

lg.l: How fitly Night turns Day, and Darkneſs flyes,
When the true Sun that never ſets doth riſe!

lg.head: Upon Thomas the Apoſtle.
lg.l: Unleſs confirm'd by Sight, there is in thee
No faith, no faith will ever, Thomas, be.

lg.head: In Judam.
lg.l: Morte quid efficies, ſi fers fera fata ſalute?
Oſcula ſi feriunt, vulnera quid facient?

lg.head: In noctem Chriſti natalem.
lg.l: Quid ni diem nox datura,
Verum ſolem paritura?

lg.head: In Thomam Apoſtolum.
lg.l: Si tibi, ni rebus fuerit firmata videndis,
Non erit ulla fides, non erit ulla fides.

lg.head: Of the image of death.
lg.l: In this one Image every man we ſee
Who was, who is, in future who ſhall be.

lg.head: In imaginem mortis.
lg.l: Haec una imago eſt omnium
Quot ſunt, fuêre, quotq, erunt.

lg.head: To the Hetruſcan Poet.
lg.l: Steal not, Hetruſcan Poet, Verſes here;
Cur Momus barks at ſuch Thieves; come not near.

lg.head: On Zoilus.
lg.l: Still whom I love, dye. Zoilus for this end,
Although I hate thee, thou ſhalt be my friend.

lg.head: Upon Phyllis.
lg.l: Much Joy brings Death: and Phyllis means no leſs,
Who therefore loves to kill with happineſs.

lg.head: To Teſtylus.
lg.l: Loves fire, O Teſtylus, none can conceal:
The Cough, Love, and the Scab, themſelves reveal.

lg.head: Upon Phyllis.
lg.l: Phyllis hath ſpots; and while that ſhe hath ſo,
Thoſe Stars for Spots, and Spots for Stars ſhall go.

lg.head: Of Marcus.
lg.l: Marcus no Muſick hath; yet ſtill he ſhakes
His Heels: A full Purſe the beſt Muſick makes.

lg.head: Pamphilu's Tombe.
lg.l: You a chief Lover were, and Love with thee
Half-buried mourns thine, and his Obſequy.

lg.head: Ad Poetam Hettuſcum.
lg.l: Non huc furatum venias, Hetruſce poeta;
Furibus oblatrat pro cane Momus; abi.

lg.head: In Zoilum.
lg.l: Omnes quotquot amo, pereunt. Te, Zoile, quamvis
Sis odioſus, amo; ſcilicet, ut pereas.

lg.head: In Phyllida.
lg.l:
Laetitiâ quoniam nimiâ pleroſ
que periſſe
Novimus; ut moriar, me mea Phyllis amat.

lg.head: Ad Teſtylum.
lg.l: Teſtyle, nemo poteſt celare Cupidinis ignes;
Tuſſis, amor, ſcabies ſunt manifeſta mala.

lg.head: In Phyllida.
lg.l: Phyllis habet maculas: maculas dum Phyllis habebit,
In coelo ſtabunt ſydera pro maculis.

lg.head: Ad Marcum.
lg.l: Perpetuò ſalt as, nullo tibi, Marce, ſonante;
Nam tibi pro cythara, Marce, crumena ſonat.

lg.head: Pamphili ſepulchrum.
lg.l:
Pamphile, totus amor ſueras, lacrymiſ
que ſepulchrum
Irrigat híc tecum ſemiſepultus amor.

lg.head: Of a beautifull Youth in arms.
lg.l: As Venus Mars, Mars Venus ſought, when thee
They ſaw, Both thought each other they did ſee.

lg.head: De puero armato.
lg.l:
Mars Venerem, Martem
que Venus dum quaerit, uter
que
Quaeſitum, viſo te, reperiſſe putant.

lg.head: Of Lycus.
lg.l: You ask why Lycus beard, not head is gray?
I'me oftner tir'd in th' Throat then Brain, he'le ſay.

lg.head: De Lyco.
lg.l: Candidior cur barba Lycus ſit crine rogatus,
Saepê fatigor, ait, guttere, non cerebro.

lg.head: De Lyco.
lg.l: Candidior cur barba Lycus ſit crine rogatus,
Saepê fatigor, ait, guttere, non cerebro.

lg.head: To Caeſar.
lg.l: Thy Souldier, Caefar, how to conquer knows,
But only thou how to forgive thy foes.

lg.head: Caeſari.
lg.l: Gloria vincendi juncta eſt cum milite, Caeſar;
Caeſar, parcendi gloria ſola tua eſt.

lg.head: On a fooliſh Drunkard.
lg.l: All drunk; he would be ſober thought: thus he
Both drunk with wine and folly proved to be.

lg.head: On the picture of Pythagoras.
lg.l: The Painter could have made Pythagoras ſpeak;
But then he ſhould his laws of Silence break.

lg.head: In Fatuum.
lg.l: Ebriierant omnes, Fatuus vult ſobrius eſſe,
Hinc ſolus viſus ebrius & fatuus.

lg.head: In Pythagoram pictum.
lg.l: Pythagoram pictor poterat pinxiſſe loquentem,
Verum Pythagoram conticuiſſe juvat.

lg.head: On St. Gregories Gueſts.
lg.l: Bleſt Saint, twice Six poor men you feaſt: for which
Angels augment thy number, and enrich.

lg.head: In S. Gregorii menſam marmoream.
lg.l: Biſſenos jubet hîc Gregorius excipi egenos:
Sed numerum excedens angelus accubitat.

lg.head: Of Poggius the Hiſtorian.
lg.l: His Country Poggius prayſeth, Foes doth curſe,
No Subject better is, Hiſtorian worſe.

lg.head: To Aeglen.
lg.l: If, Aeglen, I am Phoebus, Jove to thee,
Why be'nt you Daphne, Danaë to me.

lg.head: Of the younger Ferdinand.
lg.l: Antilochus for Years he is; for Deeds
You'l think he three-aged Neſtor far exceeds.

lg.head: De Poggio Hiſtorico,
lg.l: Dum patriam laudat, damnat dum Poggius hoſtem,
Nec malus est arvis, nec bonus hiſtoricus.

lg.head: Ad Aeglen.
lg.l: Si tibi ſunt Phoebus, ſi ſum tibi Jupiter, Aegle,
Cur tu non Daphne ſis mihi, non Danaë.

lg.head: In Ferdinandum juniorem.
lg.l: Si merita audieris Fernandi, Neſtora credas:
Si numeres annos, dixeris Antilochum.

lg.head: Of one glorying in his ſight.
lg.l: Surpaſſing Lynceus, all things well you ſee:
Who ſees all well, ſees not ſufficiently.

lg.head: To Dionyſius Athanaſine.
lg.l: Let golden mean in every action ſhine:
Be Friend to all, that all men may be thine.

lg.head: In quendam viſu gloriantem.
lg.l: Certè ego ſat video: magis eſto Lynceus ipſe;
Qui rectum omno videt, non ſatis ille videt.

lg.head: Ad Dionyſium Athanaſium.
lg.l: Fac modus in rebus tibi ſit, Jovis optime fili,
Et bonus eſto aliis, ut tibi ſis melior.

lg.head: Upon Pamphilus.
lg.l: Still you ſend Wine to me, ſtill Wine: now know,
If you would pleaſe me more, then Thirſt beſtow.

lg.head: To Laurentius.
lg.l: The Civick Oaken Crown you well may have,
Who do not one, but every Subject ſave.

lg.head: On Albiera taken away by a too ſudden fate, To her Father.
lg.l: In Heaven your daughter lives; de'e weep to be
Albiera's Father now a Deity.

lg.head: To Prince Galeotus.
lg.l: Gifts why he brings not promis'd long ago,
Ask you your Poet? He's a Poet know.

lg.head: To Franciſcus.
lg.l: Envy her ſelf, Franciſcus, never bit,
He did ſo well, him who againſt her writ.

lg.head: In Pamphilum.
lg.l: Mattis vina mihi; mihi, Pamphile, vina ſuperſunt:
Vis magè quod placeat mittere? mitte ſitim.

lg.head: Ad Laurentium.
lg.l: Quam benè glandiferâ eingis tua tempora quercu,
Qui civem ſervas non modò, ſed populum!

lg.head: In Albieram fato immaturo ereptam. Ad genitorem.
lg.l: Quid quereris genitor? vivit tua filia coelo
Albiera: annè deam progenuiſſe doles?

lg.head: Ad Galeotum Principem.
lg.l: Cur promiſſa tibi tuus poeta
Nondum praeſtiterit rogas? poeta eſt.

lg.head: Ad Franciſcum.
lg.l: Scripſit in invidiam quidam, Franciſce, poeta
Tam benè, tam doctè, nullus ut invideat.

lg.head: On a Marble Cupid; being part of the Armes of Borgia.
lg.l: Admire not Atlas made by Gorgon ſtone;
When Love by Borgia's ſight is Marble grown.

lg.head: In Cupidinem marmoreum ſuper Leonis ſpolia dormientem, Borgiae inſignia.
lg.l: Gorgone quid mirum Lybicus ſi duruit Atlas?
Lumine Borgiados ſaxificatus amor.

lg.head: On the death of Peter Bembus.
lg.l: All Rivers flow with tears, but Helicon
Still ebbing with thy Life, is dry, thou gon.

lg.head: In mortem Petri Bembi.
lg.l: Morte tua fluxit lachrymis & Tybris, & Armus,
Bembe, ſed Aioniis aruit unda v dis.

lg.head: Both good and bad men are to be regarded.
lg.l: The Romans ſo not only did implore
Their Goddeſs Health, but Plague and Scab adore.

lg.head: Upon Vulpone.
lg.l: Vulpon's ſmooth words take not me: Bad men
When ſeeming Saints, are very Devils then.

lg.head: Boni colendi & mali.
lg.l: Romula ſic olim non tantùm turba Salutem,
Cum ſcabie ſaevam ſed coluere Febrem.

lg.head: In Vulpeculam.
lg.l: Blanditur vulpes, ſed non ego credulus illi:
Peſſimus eſt ſimulans ſe malus eſſe bonum.

lg.head: On the pictures of Sleep and Drunkenneſs.
lg.l: Well might Apelles paint us lively thus;
We both were with him when he painted us.

lg.head: To Philomuſus.
lg.l: Only dead wits you like, if ſo it be,
May'ſt thou ne're like, O Philomuſus, me.

lg.head: In ſomni & ebrietatis effigies.
lg.l: Tam bellè, haud mirum eſt, ſi nos expreſſit Apelles;

Huic praeſens quando piaxit uter
que fuit.

lg.head: Ad Philomuſum:
lg.l: Si niſi defunctos laud as, Philomuſe poetas,
Me tibi perpetuò displicuiſse velim.

lg.head: Upon a Fly drown'd in a golden Cup.
lg.l: Being drown'd in this rich Wine, I could not have
A ſweeter Death, nor a more glorious Grave.

lg.head: De Muſcâ ſculptâ in aureâ phialâ.
lg.l: Aurato in cyatho dum Corſica guſto, nequivi
Snaviùs extingui, ſplendidi úſq, tegi.

lg.head: Let Chriſt's Members reſemble their Head.
lg.l: Our Head being Crown'd with Throms, O how can we
Go cloath'd in ſilks, and yet his Members be!

lg.head: Non decet ſub capite ſpinoſo membra eſſe delicata.
lg.l: Confixum spînis caput eſt, cur ſubdita membra
Tam delicati nos ſumus!

lg.head: The ſaying of King Alphoaſus.
lg.l: A Thouſand pound of Cares if thou doſt lay
Againſt a Debt, 'twill not one Farthing pay.

lg.head: Alphonſi regis dictum.
lg.l: Non mille pondo triſtium aegritudinum
Solvant vel unum debiti teruncium.

lg.head: A Living Sacrifice.
lg.l: Offer no Oxe, thou thy ſelf Victim fall,
A Living Sacrifice or none at all.

lg.head: Chriſt's Burial.
lg.l: Chriſt conquering Death by dying, did perſue
The vanquiſh'd Foe to th' Grave his Caſtle too.

lg.head: His Epitaph.
lg.l: Here Jeſus lyes: the Miracles of whom
Do ſpeak him God, though but a man the Tomb.

lg.head: Victima viva.
lg.l: Nemo bovem Domino, ſed ſe nunc immolet ipſum,
Victima nulla Deo jam niſi viva placet.

lg.head: Chriſti ſepultura.
lg.l: Mortem qui moriens vicit, nunc ut domet, ipſam
Perſequitur victam mortuus in tumulum.

lg.head: Epitaphium.
lg.l: Hoc ſaxo Chriſtus tegitur, quem vera loquuntur
Fata fuiſſe hominem, facta fuiſſe Deum.

lg.head: Upon the departure of a Friend.
lg.l: That my Friend's gone I grieve, but cannot weep,
The reaſon's plain, that Friend mine Eyes doth keep.

lg.head: Of Bees caught in a Cobweb.
lg.l: O Luxury! baſe Spiders now deſpiſe
Their common fare, and covet honey flyes.

lg.head: Fulco King of Jeruſalem, kill'd by a fall from his Horſe.
lg.l: Think not, O Kings, Death flowly comes; the ſame
To make more haſt to me on horſe-back came.

lg.head: Amico intimo Romam evocate.
lg.l: Et doleo, & nequeo fugientem flere ſodalem;
Cauſa ſubeſt, oculos abſtulit ille mihi.

lg.head: De apiculis ab aranea interceptis.
lg.l: Quas gula delicias affectat? aranea muſcas
Nauſeat; Hybleas jam ſibi poſcit aves.

lg.head: Fulco Rex Hieroſolymorum equi lapſu occiſus.
lg.l: Veſtra quid, ô reges, fore funera lento putatis?
Ut properaret, equo mors mea vecta fuit.

lg.head: Julius Caeſar the Emperor.
lg.l: If Caeſar's birth his Mother's death become,
What Woman now would bear the head of Rome?

lg.head: To a Bald man.
lg.l: A Pious reverence unto them is due
Whom Grey-hairs crown: this ne're can be to you.

lg.head: Julius Caeſar Imperator.
lg.l: Ex utero matris Caeſar ſi caeditur, ecquae
Alterius mater Caeſaris eſſe velit?

lg.head: Ad Calvum.
lg.l: Debetur canis reverentia ſancta capillis;
Debetur capiti, Calve, quid ergo tuo?

lg.head: To an o'd Man marrying a young Laſſe.
lg.l: This fair young Laſſe is not thy Wife; for ſhe
Marryes thy Neighbours, Old man, and not thee.

lg.head: Seni juvenculam ducenti, Nuptiale.
lg.l: Chare ſenex, juvenis tibi ducta puella videtur:
Ah non! vicinis eſt ea ducta tuis.

lg.head: On a Verſifier.
lg.l: Low Vecſe you call Heroick; ſuch as theſe
Learned Apollo ſtiles ſad Elegies.

lg.head: Upon Pilate.
lg.l: Ask you what's Truth, Dire Pilate? ſee it here;
In Chriſt both Truth, and Life, and Way appear.

lg.head: Upon a curious Queſtioniſt.
lg.l: How Bodies laſt in hell doſt thou inquire?
As Salamanders in Terreſtrial fire.

lg.head: Upon Matthias Berneggerus.
lg.l: Our Schools vaſt Treaſure, and chief Fame you are:
O may't be long e're I ſhall ſay you were.

lg.head: In Verſificatorem.
lg.l: Heroos mittis verſus, miſerabile metrum;
Inſcribas elegos doctus Apollo jubet.

lg.head: In Pilatum.
lg.l: Nobile quid verum veſtigas, dire Pilate?
Quod quaeris, praeſens corpore Chriſtus adejt.

lg.head: In rationiſtam.
lg.l: Flammâ ſcrutaris Stygiâ cur corpore durent?
Terreſtris vivat cur Salamandra vide.

lg.head: In Matthium Berneggerum.
lg.l: Eſt Berneggerus noſtri laus, gemma, Lycaei;
Fac Deus ut tardè dicere cogar, erat.

lg.head: Whether Sleep be the Image of Death.
lg.l: That Sleep's Death's Image I ſhall not deny;
Yet when I next would ſteep I would not dye.

lg.head: Why the Sea is ſalt.
lg.l: Why the Sea's ſalt dy'c ask? The Fiſh I fear
Would ſoon carrowſe too much if ſweet it were.

lg.head: An Ejaculation.
lg.l: Command, bleſt God, yet give me power to do.
That I may know thy Way, and walk it too.

lg.head: On a Lyer.
lg.l: Lyers ſhould have good Mem'ries; but alas
Thy Lyes thy Memory doth far ſurpaſs.

lg.head: Upon the unprofitable Servant.
lg.l: If I ſtill fruitleſs be performing all;
That man who nothing doth, what will befall?

lg.head: On a painted Lady.
lg.l: Your Beauty you in th' Viol put, alaſs!
Your Beautie's far more brittle than your Glaſs.

lg.head: On an Almanack-maker. i
lg.l: When you write fair it rains; God, you reply,
Forbids, making him Author of your Ly.

lg.head: An ſomnus ſit mortis imago.
lg.l: Propter me liceat! ſit ſomnus mortis imago.
At dormire quidem cum volo, nolo meri.

lg.head: Cur mare ſalſum.
lg.l: Cur mare ſit ſalſum, cauſas ſi quaeritis, inquam;
Potarent piſces, ſi mare dulce, nimis.

lg.head: Suſpirium.
lg.l: Sancte Deus, manda quod vis, & perfice mecum:
Da mihi noſſe bonum, da mihi poſſe ſimul.

lg.head: In mendacem.
lg.l: Mendacem ſemper memorem decet eſſe; ſed ohe,
Tu plus mentiris, quàm memor eſſe potes.

lg.head: In inutilem ſervum.
lg.l: Quando ſum inutiliter, cum foci ſingula, ſervus;
Eheu, nil quando fecero, qualis ero?

lg.head: In fucatam.
lg.l: Quae fragili teſtâ formam complecteris; ehcu!
Eſt tua quàm verè forma bonum fragile.

lg.head: In ſcriptorem Calendariorum ineptum.
lg.l: Quandò jubar ſcribis, pluit; at Deus impedit, inquis:
Quicquid mentiris, dicis id eſſe Dei.

lg.head: Juſtice in the extream.
lg.l: If extream Right be extream Wrong, what men
Would Judges wiſh to be, or Lawyers then?

lg.head: Jus ſummum.
lg.l: Quandò jus ſummum ſumma eſt injuria, ſummus
Juris. conſultus quis precor eſſe velit?

lg.head: P. Virgilius Maro.
lg.l: Virgil's Augustus like: ſole Monarch he
In Rome doth reign, Maro in Poetry.

lg.head: Aur. Propertius.
lg.l: Thy Poet crown with prayſe; for, Cynthia, he
Is Cynthius like in Deifying thee.

lg.head: P. Virgilius Maro.
lg.l:
Convenit Auguſto vates auguſtus; uter
que
Non habet Auguſtus, Virgiliuſve parem.

lg.head: Aur. Propertius.
lg.l: Cynthia plaude tuo vati: tibi Cynthius ille
Ceu deus eſt, à quo ceu dea nomen habes.

lg.head: On Gellia.
lg.l: That you are black, Gellia, they falſly ſay:
Thou art blood-red, taking thy Skin away.

lg.head: In Gelliam.
lg.l: Gellia, tenigram perhibent; haud, Gellia, nigra es:

Excipiendo cutem, Gellia, nam
que rubes.

lg.head: Ul. Huttenus.
lg.l: Hutten both Mars, and Muſes ſerves; thus he
Glory of War is, and of Poetry.

lg.head: Eobanus Heſſus.
lg.l: When in Elyzium, Heſſus, Ovid thee
Did meet, he thought he himſelf did ſee.

lg.head: Euſtach. Gnobeldorfius.
lg.l: Who ſtiles thee Roman for thy Works, the ſame
Thinks thee a rude Barbarian for thy Name.

lg.head: In Germanos Poetas. Ul. Huttenus.
lg.l:
Huttenus Muſas ſemper, Martem
que
ſecutus,
Gloria Muſarum, gloria Martis grat.

lg.head: Eobanus Heſſus.
lg.l: Elyſis Heſſum Pelignus viderat agris
Vates, atq, umbram credidit eſſe ſuam.

lg.head: Euſtach. Gnobeldorſius.
lg.l: Qui tua ſcriptaleget, Latio juraverit ortum:
Qui nomen, dicet, Barbarus iſte fuit.

lg.head: On the picture of H. Grotius.
lg.l: Grotius his youth you in this Piece ſurvey:
Old Ariſtotle in his Works you may.

lg.head: Of the Dutch.
lg.l: Spaniard, the Dutch invincible doth prove:
No War, no Siege will conquer them, but Love.

lg.head: Of the death of Cato.
lg.l: Many lived proudly, Cato dy'd: now ſay
Who are moſt fooliſh, Plutarch, he or they.

lg.head: In effigiem H. Grotii.
lg.l: Grotius effigie puer hac florebat: amice,
Dic vidiſſe ſenem, lector, Ariſtotelem.

lg.head: De Batavo.
lg.l: Invictum patriâ pro libertate Batavum
Vincere quo ritu poſſit Iberus? amet.

lg.head: De morte Catonis.
lg.l: Vixerunt multi, Cato mortuus ambitiosè eſt;
Utri ſunt, ô Plutarche, magis fatui.

lg.head: Of the death of John Lauterbachius.
lg.l: Phoebus thy Verſe did envy; he, thy Fate,
And not the Parcae, did anticipate.

lg.head: Of Priſca.
lg.l: Priſca, though rich in Vertue, and in Gold
No Suiter hath: her Name doth ſpeak her old.

lg.head: To John Ortelius his Schoolmaſter.
lg.l: You Argus are; yet when our exerciſe
You do peruſe, lay by your hundred Eyes.

lg.head: Joannes Lauterbachii poetae nobilis tumulus.
lg.l: Te, Lauterbachi, Phoebus, non Parca necabat;
Ne ſuperaretur carmine, cauſa fuit.

lg.head: Priſcae, virgini Lavinganae.
lg.l: Dives es, & caſta es: cur eſt tibi nullus amator?
Prodere quòd nomen, Priſca, videtur anum.

lg.head: Joanni Ortelio, praeceptori ſuo.
lg.l: Argus es, Orteli, centeno lumine. Noſtris
In ſcriptis, ut ſis talpa, rogare placet.

lg.head: Of the Law.
lg.l: If extream Juſtice be unjuſt, ſuch men
As are moſt juſt are the unjuſteſt then.

lg.head: Of Gellia.
lg.l: Gellia the Hangman doth, not Doctor chooſe:
The quickeſt courſe of Phyſick is the Nooſe.

lg.head: To Phoebus.
lg.l: Phoebus farewell, my utmoſt Race is run:
Enough if good, if bad, too much is done.

lg.head: De Jure.
lg.l: Si bene dicatur jus ſummum injuria ſumma;
Quiſquis erit ſumme juſtus, iniquus erit.

lg.head: De Gellia.
lg.l: Carnifici mallet, medico quàm Gellia tradi:
Nam mors non poenam, ſed mora mortis habet:

lg.head: Ad Phoebum.
lg.l: Phoebe vale, extremam tetigerunt carmina metam:
Si bona, multa ſatis; ſi mala, multa nimis.

lg.head: Upon Neſtor.
lg.l: Neſtor three ages lived; no wonder then
He wiſer was, being older than all men.

lg.head: In Neſtorem.
lg.l: Quid mirum? ſeclis vixerat ille tribus.

lg.head: Of a Lawyer and his ſcolding wife.
lg.l: Mallus and Iſſa well agree: the Hall
He fills with clamours, ſhe at home doth brawle.

lg.head: De cauſidico & uxore rixosâ.
lg.l: Quam benè conveniunt ſociati Mallus & Iſſa;
Litigat ille foro! litigat iſta domi.

lg.head: To Sir Philip Sidney.
lg.l: Wit, Learning, Wiſdome, Valour, Birth: we ſee,
In few theſe Single, All conjoyn'd in thee.

lg.head: Upon one that prays'd and not practis'd Vertue.
lg.l: No wonder Vertue comes not ne're thy heart;
When from thy tongue it never doth depart.

lg.head: D. Philippo Sidnaeo.
lg.l: Ingenium, doctrina, genus, prudeutia, virtus;
Haec data ſunt paucis ſingula, cuncta tibi.

lg.head: In quendam virtutis Encomiaſten.
lg.l: Semper in ore tibi eſt virt us, tamen exulat illa
Pectore: ſcin' cauſam, ſemper in ore tibi eſt.

lg.head: To Olus of Flaccus.
lg.l: Fat-belly'd Flaccus is; you laugh at it:
Yet, Olus, you have a far fatter wit.

lg.head: Of Janus Secundus.
lg.l: Cupid, and Venus, Janus prays'd ſo well,
His Verſes did their Beauties far excell.

lg.head: De Flacco ad Olum.
lg.l: Quid multo pinguem rides abdomine Flaccum?
Ingenium multò pinguius, Ole, tibi eſt.

lg.head: De Jano Secundo.
lg.l: Dum Veneris cantat puerum cum matre Secundus,
Ipſi omnes Veneri ſurripuit Veneres.

lg.head: Of Narciſſus.
lg.l: That Breaſt, whoſe Ice no Driads flames could turn,
And thaw to Love, Water it ſelf doth burn.

lg.head: De Narciſſo.
lg.l: Hunc arſit quondam Driadum pulcherima; nymphae
Frigidus ad flammas, fontis aquá incalvit.

lg.head: On Sertorius.
lg.l: Sertorius prays not that his Wife might dye;
He only beggs her Immortality.

lg.head: To Candida.
lg.l: Nor Gods, nor Men, thee, Candida, can move;
Yet you enflame both Men, and Gods, with Love.

lg.head: In Sertorium.
lg.l: Conjugis haud optat mortem Sertorius, optat
Hoc tantum, aeternos vivat ut illa di • s.

lg.head: Ad Candidam.
lg.l: Quòd te non homines moveant, non Candida, divi;
Hoc potes una homines, una movere deos.

lg.head: On Sabellus.
lg.l: Of all thoſe good things which the World contains,
It ſtill wants Vertue, Sabell, only means.

lg.head: In Sabellum.
lg.l: De tot, de tantis quibus urbs, quibus orbis abundat,

Sola deest virtus, reſ
que
Sabelle, tibi.

lg.head: To Linus.
lg.l: You ſaid you'd write, yet ſince you married are:
O, I excuſe, you're not the man you were.

lg.head: Ad Linum.
lg.l: Promittis toties; & adhuc, Line, ſcribere ceſſas?
Duxi, ais, uxorem: do veniam, haud tuus es.

lg.head: What to learn, and how to live.
lg.l: Learn as if Neſtor's years ſhould fall to thee:
Live as if Death ſhould come immediately.

lg.head: Quantum diſcendum, quomodò vivendum.
lg.l: Diſce, velut ſeri victurus Neſtoris annos,

Vive, velut tibi ſit ultima quae
que dies.

lg.head: Upon Hercules bearing a Cupid.
lg.l: Once the vaſt Heavens were light to thee; now Love
A Little boy doth far too heavy prove.

lg.head: In imaginem Herculis Cupidinem geſtantis.
lg.l: Ante quibus coelum ſuerat leve pondus, eiſdem
Nunc gravis eſt humeris ſarcina parvus amor.

lg.head: On a Horſe taken in fight.
lg.l: No common part of Belgia's ſpoyl was I;
Rather than flight chooſing Captivity.

lg.head: On the Sail-bearing Chariots of the moſt Illuſtrious Prince Mauricius.
lg.l: Look you with wonder, Phoebus? ſo you may:
For this our Chariot will out run thy Day.

lg.head: A Sword.
lg.l: This Sword which now you hanging idle ſee,
Once through the Spaniards ſide ſought Victory.

lg.head: A Toleto Blade.
lg.l: Not for his Gold Tagus is fam'd alone,
But for his gold-excelling Steel is known.

lg.head: A piece of Ordinance.
lg.l: Theſe are the ſureſt Inſtruments of Fate;
Which Jove in Thunder learn'd to imitate.

lg.head: A Desk.
lg.l: Sent Healths lie here: could I communicate,
I ſhould grow rich though ſelling under rate.

lg.head: A Sand-box.
lg.l: When to your Danae you write, with Sand
Of Gold ſprinkle your Letter, and command.

lg.head: Silver Pieces to caſt up account with.
lg.l: Regard your gains well, Counters; for if we
Do money want, your ſelves ſhall money be.

lg.head: A Top and a Scurge to a Boy.
lg.l: You laſh your Top that did no fault commit:
When you ſhould rather Whipping have then it.

lg.head: Dutch Pattins.
lg.l: Go, yet not go, your Hogen-ſteel-ſhoed-man
Upon the water, yet no water, can.

lg.head: Spectacles.
lg.l: You hardly with your pocket eyes do ſee:
Lay them a ſide, and you ſtark blind will be.

lg.head: A Sun-dial.
lg.l: Contracted ſhadows pointing Noon I'le ſee
No more: my Belly ſhall my Dial be.

lg.head: The Celeſtial Globe.
lg.l: What need'ſt thou to ſearch Heaven for ſtars? thoſe Sphere
Inhabitants do in thy houſe appear.

lg.head: A pair of Tongues.
lg.l: That man who firſt the uſe of Tongs found out,
With untry'd fire his fingers burnt, no doubt.

lg.head: A Warming-pan.
lg.l: With inclos'd fire, from your moyſt ſheets the wet
Diſtill, leaſt you ſhould quaking find them ſweat.

lg.head: A Band.
lg.l: We ſtarch with juyce of Wheat: this grain proves good,
Both for our daily ornament and food.

lg.head: A Womon's Mask.
lg.l: Fowler then dirt you are, black as a More:
You need no Mask, for you are Mask all o're.

lg.head: A plain Wedding Ring.
lg.l: This Wedding Ring is Gold, yet plain withall;
The Proverb thus doth Plaineſs Golden call.

lg.head: A Woman's Bracelet.
lg.l: That Bracelet on thy Arm but ſlack doth fit;
The which if mine, would ſcarce my finger fit.

lg.head: Chryſtal Cups.
lg.l: Your Chryſtal Cup's high priz'd, the more for this,
That being So, it ſo ſoon nothing is.

lg.head: A Golden Cup.
