lg.l: In the beſt mettle Maurice health ſhould ſhine,
And richer then the Plate ſhould be the Wine.

lg.head: A perfumed Glove.
lg.l: Let the ſtrong Dog skin ſheath my hand, if that
May be perfum'd by the Sabaan Cat.

lg.head: In equum captum in praeſio.
lg.l: Pars ego Flandriaci non contemnenda triumphi
Praeda fui, fierem ne fugientis equus.

lg.head: In illuſtriſſimi Principis Mauritii currus veliferos. Currus loquitur.
lg.l: Phoebe, quid attonitus nos aspicis? aspice vero:
Hoc curru poteras accelerare diem.

lg.head: Enſis.
lg.l: Otia qui gemino pendens agit enſis in unce,
Ivit in Albani militis ille latus.

lg.head: Gladius Toletanus.
lg.l: Unda Tagi non eſt uno celebranda metallo:
Utilis in cives eſt ibi lamna ſuos.

lg.head: Bombarda.
lg.l: Certius haec tangunt inimicas tela cohortes.
Fallor? an hinc didicit Jupiter eſſe tonans.

lg.head: Pluteus.
lg.l: Scrinia perlatas ſervant mihi mille ſalutes:
Si modico poſſem vendere, dives eram.

lg.head: Pixis arenaria.
lg.l: Pu ••• ris aurati pluvia ſit ſparſa papyrus:
Reſcribet Danae ſollicitata, veni.

lg.head: Calculi argentei.
lg.l: Calcule ſac noſtris faveas argentee lucris:

Si deerunt nummi, tu quo
que nummus eris.

lg.head: Turbo cum ſcutica. Ad puerum.
lg.l: Quid meruit turbo, quem tu vibice fatigas?
Haec natibus fuerant debita flagra tuis.

lg.head: Soleae ferratae.
lg.l: Quae Battavûm miratur hyems ſola ferrea cernis?
His per aquas, nec aquas, ire, nec ire, licet.

lg.head: Perſpicillae.
lg.l: Vix spectas vitreis jam luſcitioſus ocellis:
Haec ſi perdideris lumina, coecus eris.

lg.head: Sciatheris.
lg.l: Da • t medios ſoles contractae gnomonis umbrae:
At mihi pro tali gnomone, venter erit.

lg.head: Sphaera coeleſtis.
lg.l:
Sidereos vultus, cantata
que vatibus aſtra
Non opus eſt coelo quaerere, quaere domi,

lg.head: Forceps.
lg.l: qui populis bifidi monſtravit forcipis uſus,
Primus inexperto laeſerat igne manus.

lg.head: Batillus lectarius.
lg.l: Igne, ſed incluſo, ſi quid tua fila biberunt,
Decoque; ne lectus ſudet, & ipſe tremas.

lg.head: Collare lineum.
lg.l: Caerula triticeus pingit collaria ſuccus:
Non alimur tantum farre, ſed induimur.

lg.head: Larva puellaris.
lg.l: Pulvere ſordidior vultus, cute nigrior Indâ,
Quid timet? an larvae non ſatis ipſa fuit?

lg.head: Annulus pronubus purus.
lg.l: Pignus habes fidei nullis violabile gemmis:
Hoc illud vetus eſt; aurea ſimplicitas.

lg.head: Armilla puellaris.
lg.l: Si mihi, brachiolum claudit quae parva ſiniſtrum,
Armillam dederis, annulus eſſe poteſt.

lg.head: Vitrea pocula.
lg.l: Materies fragilis commendat pocula vitrum:
Est aliquid, fieri tam citò poſſe nihil.

lg.head: Calix aureus.
lg.l: Non ſortûita dabis pretioſa vina metallo,
Sed pro Mauritii digna ſalute bibi.

lg.head: Chirotheca odorata.
lg.l: Vaginam manibus cupio de pelle caninâ,
Sed quae Sabeaeae ſtercora felis olet.

lg.head: A Dove the Image of the Holy Ghoſt.
lg.l: The God of Peace, and Birds of Peace agree;
Thoſe Birds a clean Houſe love, a clean Heart he.

lg.head: Of the crucifying of our Saviour and Saint Peter.
lg.l: Chriſt's feet were down plac'd, Peter's up, which ſhows
Chriſt from the Croſs deſcended, Peter roſe.

lg.head: Chriſt ſuffering on Friday, Venus day.
lg.l: On Venus day Chriſt dy'd, which doth imply
Venus a chief cauſe was that he did dye.

lg.head: Silence.
lg.l: Silence than Speech is greater Art; of it
None ever did, many of Speech have writ.

lg.head: On the Daughter of Herodias being drown'd.
lg.l: Such as thy Life, a ſoft and dancing Wave
Hath juſtly been to thee both Death and Grave.

lg.head: To John Brantius, of his Epigrams.
lg.l: If you ſee nothing bad, with Love you're blind:
You're ſo with Envy, if none good you find.

lg.head: Law and Strife.
lg.l: Law is Strife's Child: Strife Law's: Thus we may ſee
Good come of Bad, Bad of Good Pedtgree.

lg.head: Mnemoſyne Mother of the Muſes.
lg.l: Why do nine Letters ſpell Muemoſyne?
Thoſe Letters and her Daughters equal be.

lg.head: To Marianus of Camillus the Covetous.
lg.l: You prayſe Camillus keeping Wealth; thus you
Give that to him, which to his Trunks is due.

lg.head: On Domitian the Emperour who could ſhoot between the fingers of a Boy placed at a great diſtance.
lg.l: I cannot prayſe thee, Caeſar; for if ſo
You alwayes ſhoot, you'l never hit your foe.

lg.head: On the death of Lipſius.
lg.l: Some in rich Parian ſtone, in Ivory,
And Marble ſome, Lipſius in tears doth lye.

lg.head: Of the Dove and Serpent. To Marinus.
lg.l: A Dove, that thou mayſt injure not one, be:
A Serpent's wit aſſume that none may thee.

lg.head: The Spirit and Fleſh.
lg.l: Why doth our Fleſh ſtronger than Soul appear?
Our Fleſh at home is, Soul an exile here.

lg.head: Of the birth and death of Chriſt.
lg.l: Good Night when born, Bad Day when Crucified;
A Birth-day-night; A Dooms-day when he dyed.

lg.head: On the death of Chriſtopher Clavius.
lg.l: When doubting of ſome ſtars, thus Clavius cry'd,
Let me, O God nearer behold, and dyed.

lg.head: On the death of Abſolon.
lg.l: Doubting the hairs juſt weight, to know the truth
The Tree by his own hair did weigh the Youth.

lg.head: On Puppus the Dwarf.
lg.l: Thus Puppus dying did his Friends adviſe;
No Coffin buy, a Box will me ſuffice.

lg.head: Spiritus Sancti imago, columba.
lg.l:
I'lle Deus pacis, volucres hae pacis; amant
que
Candida tecta illae, candida corda Deus.

lg.head: De Chriſto Domino & Petro Apoſtolo crucifixis.
lg.l:
Cur Petri ſurſum plantae, Chriſti
que deorſum?
Sub terras ibat Chriſtus, in aſtra Petrus.

lg.head: Die Veneris Chriſtus paſſus.
lg.l: Luce obiit Veneris, Veneris fle turba; videtur
Cauſa Dei paſſi non minima eſse Venus.

lg.head: Tacere.
lg.l: Dicendi ars magna eſt, major (mihi crede) tacendi;
Mille loqui docuere artes, ſed nulla tacere.

lg.head: In Herodi ••• filiam aquis •• merſam.
lg.l:
Mergere ſalatrix, mollis
〈◊〉 tibi vita,
Undarum tibi mo • s devita mollis erat.

lg.head: Ad Jo. Brantium de Muſis ſuis.
lg.l: Omnia ſi loudas mea, Branti, coecus amore es;
Omnia ſi culpas, coecus es invidiâ.

lg.head: Lex & lis.
lg.l: Filia lex litis: bona filia, peſſima mater.
Filia lis legis; mater bona, peſſima nata.

lg.head: Mnemoſyne, mater Muſarum.
lg.l: Cur te Mnemoſyne, pingit ter littera terna?
Ter terna eſt, inquit, filia docta mihi.

lg.head: Ad Marianum, de Camillo avaro.
lg.l: Quòd bene ſervet opes, laudas, Mariane, Camillum;
Scrinia laudari ſic, Mariane, ſolent.

lg.head: Domitianus Imp. inter diſtentos pueri procul poſiti digitos ſagittas dirigere norat.
lg.l: Laudem? non faciam. Nam ſi tua ſpicula in hoſtem
Sic mittis, ſanè es, Domitiane, rudis.

lg.head: In Juſti Lipſii obitum.
lg.l: Sunt buſto in Pario, ſunt qui tumulantur eburno;
Sunt qui marmoribus, Lypſius in lachrymis.

lg.head: Quid Columba, & Serpens. Ad Marinum.
lg.l: Ut nulli noceas, columba fias;
Ut nemo tibi, ſis, Marine, ſerpens.

lg.head: Anima & Caro.
lg.l: Quaeris cur animâ caro fortior? accipe cauſam;
Hìc carnis patria eſt, hìc animae exilium.

lg.head: De nato & paſſo Chriſto.
lg.l: O nati Chriſti bona nox, o lux mala paſſi!
Lux mala luce carens, nox bona nocte carens.

lg.head: In obitum Chriſtoph. Clavii.
lg.l: Clavius è terris cum jam vix ſidera noſſet,
Da Deus haec propriùs cernere, dixit; obit.

lg.head: In mortem Abſalonis.
lg.l: Davididae crines juſto librentur in auro,
Scire hoc vult arbor; librat & ipſa virum.

lg.head: In Puppum pumilionem.
lg.l: Dum moriens ſuprema animae fert frigora Puppus,
Nemo paret tumulum; pyxide condar, ait.

lg.head: Ovid.
lg.l: Caeſar condemns me: yet if Love ſhould be
My Advocate, I know I ſhould go free.

lg.head: Horace.
lg.l: His pleas'd Companions faults he reprehends;
And Lydia ſo ſpeaks his, as he his friends.

lg.head: Catullus.
lg.l: If Jove ſhould ſing his Loves, as thou doſt thine;
He'd have thee make his Verſe, like him, divine.

lg.head: Tibullus.
lg.l: Sulpitia and Neraea win thy Love,
Which to the Muſes mortal flames doth prove.

lg.head: Lucan.
lg.l: Who me no Poet counts, is none: who me
Thinks no Hiſtorian, knows leſſe Hiſtory.

lg.head: Martial.
lg.l: Slight not looſe Martial, Reader; can we blame
Him who relates Ill, when we do the ſame?

lg.head: Ovidius.
lg.l: Judice ſim quamvis damnatus Caeſare: poená
Abſolvar, cauſam ſi modò dicat amor.

lg.head: Horatius.
lg.l: Omne vafer vitium ridenti dicis amico,
Sed dicit vitium Lydia ſola tuum.

lg.head: Catullus.
lg.l: Si cantare Jovem proprios fas eſſet amores;
Hoc, & non alio poſceret ore loqui.

lg.head: Tibullus.
lg.l: Cur tibi Sulpitiae, tibi cur placuere Nerae •
Baſia, quem Muſae deperiere novem?

lg.head: Lucanus.
lg.l: Cui minus hiſtoricus credor, minus eſſe poeta;
Me minor eſt vates, & minor hiſtoricus.

lg.head: Martialis.
lg.l: Ne Feſcenninum, lector, contemne poetam;
Nam, quae nos facimus, ſit ceciniſſe parum.

lg.head: On a Proud man.
lg.l: Boaſt not thy Actions; for if bad they be,
No prayſe is due, if good, none's due to thee.

lg.head: In tumidura.
lg.l: Vel bona, vel mala ſunt, animus quibus intumet; atqui,
Si mala, laude carent; ſi bona, non tua ſunt.

lg.head: Whither penitent tears do tend.
lg.l: Rain up ſalt ſhowres, Love's ſtreams muſt upward flow:
As Fire aſcends, true fire-born tears ſhould ſo.

lg.head: Why the Serpent's skin cures the ears.
lg.l: The Serpent cures the Ear: he good is found
Too late, healing Mankind as he did wound.

lg.head: Quo poenitentis lachrymae tendant.
lg.l: Ire licet caelo, non eſt gravis imber amoris:
Ignis ut aſtra petit, ſic ſatus igne liquor.

lg.head: Cur Serpentis pellis medeatur auribus.
lg.l: Exuviis medicis ſerpens parit aure ſalutem:
Serò pius noxam quà dedit Eva piat.

lg.head: Bluſhing the ſign of Modeſty.
lg.l: The Scarlet Cheek is a moſt pleaſing dye;
For ſo much Colour, ſo much Modeſty.

lg.head: Death for the Publick.
lg.l: To ſave thy Country, loſe thy Life: he'le have
A Noble birth who ſhall thus find a Grave.

lg.head: On Sabellicus.
lg.l: Why ſwears Sabellicus? no wonder, he
A faſhion doth, not Sin think Perjury.

lg.head: Rubor pudoris ſignum.
lg.l: Rubore vultus imbui multo placet:
In ore quantum ſanguinis, pudoris eſt.

lg.head: Mors pro Patriâ.
lg.l: Animam ſaluti impende fortis publicae:
Quem ſic perire cernis, hunc naſci putes.

lg.head: In Sabellicum.
lg.l: Cur perjerat Sabellicus? perjurium
Sermonis eſſe, haud criminis putat genus.

lg.head: Of Aurispa.
lg.l: Auriſpa nothing writes, though learn'd; for he
By a wiſe Silence ſeems more learn'd to be.

lg.head: To Paul.
lg.l: What thus I carry hid, Paul, ask you me?
I'de not it hide, would I that you ſhould ſee.

lg.head: De Auriſpa.
lg.l: Tam dostus ſcribat cur nil Auriſpa, requiris?
Credatur multò doctus ut eſſe magis.

lg.head: Ad Paulum.
lg.l: Paule, ſuperjectâ quae portem veſte requiris?
Si te ſcire velim, non ea, Paule, tegam.

lg.head: Of injuries.
lg.l: Wrongs bitter are as Pills, and like them, they,
Not chew'd, but ſwallow'd whole, ſhould paſs away.

lg.head: Of his Friend.
lg.l: Write ſome brief Epitaph, my Friend ſtill cryes
Of his dead Father; briefly, Here he lyes.

lg.head: De injuria.
lg.l: Non injuria dente maſticanda,
Sed toto, ut pilula, ore devoranda.

lg.head: Ad Amicum.
lg.l: Funere de patris breviter me ſcribere mandas;
De patris breviter funcre ſcribo; jucet.

lg.head: On a covetous rich man.
lg.l: Gifts to the Poor you ſend, but with intent
Like to receive; your Alms are purchaſe meant.

lg.head: Of Sylvius.
lg.l: Sylvius that nothing gratis gave, being dead,
Grieves that his Epitaph is gratis read.

lg.head: On Zoilus.
lg.l: In vain I prayſe thee, and in vain by thee
I'me wrong'd; none credit will or you, or me.

lg.head: In divitem avarum.
lg.l: Das inopi dives, ſed qualia reddere poſſit
Munera; Nonne hoc eſt dicere? redde mihi.

lg.head: Jacobo Sylvio.
lg.l: Sylvius hic ſitus eſt, gratis qui nil dedit unquam;
Mortuus &, gratis quòd legis iſta, dolet.

lg.head: In Zoilum.
lg.l: Fruſtra ego te laudo, fruſtra me, Zoile, laedis:
Nemo mihi credit, Zoile, nemo tibi.

lg.head: God is chiefly to be worſhipt.
lg.l: If God a Spirit be as Poets ſing,
A Spirit pure ſhould be his Offering.

lg.head: 2. Drowſyneſs is to be ſhun'd.
lg.l: Wake; be not given to ſleep: for it we ſee
Is food to vice, but poyſon unto thee.

lg.head: 3. The Tongue is to be bridled.
lg.l: To guide the Tongue is the chief Vertue; be
That can rule it, is next the Deity.

lg.head: 4. Agree with thy ſelf.
lg.l: Thou with thy ſelf agree; he muſt reſiſt
Another who's his own Antagoniſt.

lg.head: 5. Blame no one raſhly:
lg.l: Mind humane nature, Carper; thou wilt ſee
Of thoſe faults thou doſt blame no one is free.

lg.head: 6. Safety is to be preferred before Wealth.
lg.l: Leave what you love, if dangerous; before
All riches, value thou rich ſafety more.

lg.head: 7. Let thy temper comply with the times.
lg.l: Change, yet ſtand firm; a wiſe man free from crime,
Dotb metamorphize manners with the time.

lg.head: 8. We muſt not alwayes yield to a wife.
lg.l: Truſt not thy Wife complaining; for it proves
Not ſeldom ſhe doth hate, whom th' Husband loves.

lg.head: 9. We muſt be urgent in the correction of a friend.
lg.l: When thou doſt counſel any, he a friend,
Though he doth ſhun th' advice, yet do not end.

lg.head: 10. Fools are not to be overcome with words.
lg.l: Talk not with Pratlers; Wiſdome and Eloquence
To few, Nature to all doth words diſpence.

lg.head: 11. Every one is a friend to himſelf.
lg.l: Be friend to others, yet thine own; ſo do
Them good, no damage may thy ſelf purſue.

lg.head: 12. It is forbid to ſpread rumours.
lg.l: Fly ſpreading rumours, be not Author ſo;
Silence hurts no one, Speech doth make thee foe.

lg.head: 13. Promiſe not for another.
lg.l: Aſſure not what another ſayes; who finds
A faith 'tis rare; many have many minds.

lg.head: 14. Let every one judge himſelf.
lg.l: Judge whether thou art worthy offer'd prayſe;
From thine own mind, not others take thy bayes.

lg.head: 15. The account of Benefits.
lg.l: A Benefit receiv'd thou ought'ſt to ſhew
To all; thy Charity let no one know.

lg.head: 16. Old men are to speak of their good deeds.
lg.l: When thou old man doſt call back time, and acts
Of others; tell thine own prayſe-worthy facts.

lg.head: 17. The fault of Suſpition.
lg.l: Suſpect not Whiſpering; the guilty mind
Doth in each word an accuſatlon find.

lg.head: 18. We muſt think of Adverſity in Proſperity.
lg.l: When thou art well, think of Adverſity.
The firſt and laſt fate ſeldome do agree.

lg.head: 19. Do not hope for anothers death.
lg.l: Why ſhould we hope anothers death to ſee?
We're all frail ſubjects to mortality.

lg.head: 20. The mind of the Giver is to be eſteem'd in the Gift.
lg.l: Thy poor Friend's gift though a ſmall benefit
Receive, but render prayſe ſurpaſſing it.

lg.head: 21. The patient enduring of poverty.
lg.l: Since by Creation naked, therefore be
Patient in bearing native Poverty.

lg.head: 22. Death is not to be fear'd.
lg.l: Fear not Life's end; he that doth ſo, doth take
Farewell of that which Life doth happy make.

lg.head: 23. Withhold thy favours from ungratefull men.
lg.l: When thou doſt meet one doth ingrateful prove,
Do not blaſpheme thy God, refrain thy love.

lg.head: 24. Frugality.
lg.l: Spare what thou haſt, that it may farther go;
That thou mayſt not be poor, think thou art ſo.

lg.head: 25. Often Promiſes are troubleſome.
lg.l: Promiſe not twice what may at firſt be done;
Perform thy promiſe, iteration ſhun.

lg.head: 26. Craft is to be deluded by Craſt.
lg.l: Who ſeems thy friend, and is not ſo, mean while
Seem thou ſo toe, and Craft with Craft beguile.

lg.head: 27. Fair words are to be ſuſpected.
lg.l: Approve not them ſpeak fair; the Fowler's fife
Sounds ſweet while the poor Bird doth loſe its life.

lg.head: 28. Children are to be iuſtructed in the Arts.
lg.l: If thou haſt Sons, and canſt no portion give,
Give Learning; they in ſpite of Fate will live.

lg.head: 29. How things are to be eſteemed.
lg.l: What's baſe eſteem'd, think brave; brave, baſe; you'l be
So doing to thy ſelf and others free.

lg.head: 30. Act not what thou doſt condemn.
lg.l: Be free from faults you blame; it is moſt baſe
When thine own doctrine doth fly in thy face.

lg.head: 31. Things not fitting to be granted, are not to be asked.
lg.l: Ask what thou mayſt have honeſtly; he muſt
Be knave and fool that doth ask what's unjuſt.

lg.head: 32. Known things are not to be chang'd for unknown.
lg.l: Change not for that you know not what you know,
You ſee this good, that only may prove ſo.

lg.head: 33. Think every day thy laſt.
lg.l: Since many deaths in every place do dwell,
Think each day gain'd, no one can fate compell.

lg.head: 34. Yield to thy friend.
lg.l: Alwayes thy friend to conquer think not fit;
True friends then conquer when they do ſubmit.

lg.head: 35. Friendſhip requires mutual curteſies.
lg.l: When thou wouldſt great Gifts have, then ſmall ones ſend;
By being gracious thus you gain a friend.

lg.head: 36. Friendſhip doth hate differences.
lg.l: Strive not with him who to thee friend doth prove;
Anger breeds hate, concord doth nouriſh love.

lg.head: 37. Chaſtiſement without anger.
lg.l: When angry with a Servant, firſt be ſlow
To Paſſion, and then thou wilt mercy ſhew.

lg.head: 38. To overcome with patience.
lg.l: By ſuff'ring conquer when it doth behoove;
Patience doth alwayes greateſt Vertue prove.

lg.head: 39. Keep what you have got.
lg.l: Keep what thou haſt; who labours to reſtore
His former loſs, doth ſtill loſe more and more.

lg.head: 40. Provide in the firſt place for thy ſelf.
lg.l: Be to thy friends a friend, but likewiſe be
So doing to thy ſelf no enemy.

lg.head: Dei cultus praecipuus.
lg.l: Si Deus eſt animus, nobis ut carmina dicum,
Hic tibi praecipue ſit pura mente colendus.

lg.head: 2. Somnolentia vitanda.
lg.l: Plus vigila ſemper, nec ſomno deditus eſto:
Nam diuturna quies vitiis alimenta miniſtrat.

lg.head: 3. Cohibenda lingua.
lg.l: Virtutem primam eſſe puta compeſcere lieguam:
Proximus ille Deo, qui ſcit ratione tacere.

lg.head: 4. Sibi ipſi conveniendum eſt.
lg.l: Sperne repugnando tibi tu contrarius eſse:
Conveniet nulli, qui ſecum diſſidet ipſo.

lg.head: 5. Nemo temere culpandus.
lg.l: Si vitam inspicias bominum, ſi denique mores,
Cum culpent alios, nemo ſine crimine vivit.

lg.head: 6. Utilitas divitiis anteponenda.
lg.l: Quae nocitura tenes, quamvis ſint chara, relinque.
Utilitas opibus praeponi tempore debet.

lg.head: 7. Mores pro tempore mutandi.
lg.l:
Constans & lenis, ut res cuu
que expoſtulat, eſto:
Temporibus mores ſapiens ſine crimine mutat.

lg.head: 8. Uxori non ſemper aſſentiendum.
lg.l: Nil temere uxori de ſervis crede querenti:
Saepe etenim mulier, quem conjux diligit, odit.

lg.head: 9. Inſtandum correctioni amici.
lg.l: Si tibi ſit charus noli deſiſtere coeptls.

lg.head: 10. Stulti verbis non vincuntur.
lg.l: Contra verboſos noli contendere verbis:
Sermo datur cunctis, animi ſapientia paucis.

lg.head: 11. Amicus ſibi quiſque.
lg.l: Dilige ſic alios, ut ſis tibi charus amicus:
Sic bonus eſto bonis, ne te mala damna ſequantur.

lg.head: 12. Rumores ſpargere vetitum.
lg.l: Rumores fuge, ne incipias novus author haberi:
Nam nulli tacuiſse nocet, nocet eſſe locutum.

lg.head: 13. Fides aliena non promittenda.
lg.l: Rem tibi promiſſam certo promittere noli.
Rara fides ideo eſt, quia multi multa loquuntur.

lg.head: 14. Judex quiſque ſui.
lg.l: Cum quis te laudat, judex tuus eſſe memento:
Plus alias de te, quam tu tibi credere noli.

lg.head: 15. Beneficiorum ratio.
lg.l: Officium alterius multis narrare memento;
Atque aliis cum tu benefeceris, ipſe ſileto.

lg.head: 16. Senio bene geſta referenda.
lg.l: Multorum dum facta ſenex & dicta recenſes,
Fac tibi ſuccurrant juvenis quae feceris ipſe.

lg.head: 17. Suſpitionis labes.
lg.l: Ne cures ſi quis tacito ſermone loquatur:
Conſcius ipſe ſibi, de ſe putat omnia dici.

lg.head: 18. In proſperis, de adverſis cogitandum.
lg.l: Cum fueris felix, quae ſunt adverſa caveto:
Non eadem curſu reſpondent ultima primis.

lg.head: 19. Mors alterius non ſperanda.
lg.l: Cum dubia & fragilis ſit nobis vita tributa,
In morte alterius spem tu tibi ponere noli.

lg.head: 20. Animus in dono aeſtimandus.
lg.l: Exiguum munus cum dat tibi pauper amicus:
Accipito placide, plene & laudare memento.

lg.head: 21. Paupertatis tolerantia.
lg.l: Infantem nudum cum te natura crearit,
Paupertatis onus patienter ferre memento.

lg.head: 22. Mors non formidanda.
lg.l: Ne time as illam, quae vitae est ultima finis.
Qui mortem motuit, quod vivit, perdit id ipſum.

lg.head: 23. Amicorum ingratitudo fugienda.
lg.l: Si tibi pro meritis nemo respondet amicus,
Incuſare Deum noli, ſed te ipſe coerce.

lg.head: 24. Frugalitas.
lg.l: Ne tibi quid deſit, quaeſitis utere parce:

Ut
que quod eſt ſerves, ſemper tibi deeſſe putate.

lg.head: 25. Promiſſio iterata moleſta.
lg.l: Quod praeſtare potes, ne bis promiſeris ulli,
Ne ſis ventoſus, dum vis urbanus haberi.

lg.head: 26. Ars arte deludenda.
lg.l: Qui ſimulat verbis, ne corde eſt fidus amicus,
Tu quo fac ſimile: ſic ars deluditur arte.

lg.head: 27. Blandiloquentia ſuſpecta.
lg.l: Noli homines blandos nimium ſermone probare:
Fiſtula dulce canit, volucrem dum decipit auceps.

lg.head: 28. Liberi artibus inſtruendi.
lg.l: Si tibi ſint nati, nec opes, tunc artibus illos
Inſtrue, quo poſſint inopem defendere vitam.

lg.head: 29. Res quomodo aeſtimandae.
lg.l: Quod vile eſt, charum; quod charum, vile putato:
Sic tibi nec parcus, nec avarus habereris ulli.

lg.head: 30. Culpata non facienda.
lg.l: Quae culpare ſoles, ea ne tu feeeris ipſe:
Turpe eſt doctori cum culpa redarguit ipſum.

lg.head: 31. Concedenda petenda.
lg.l: Quod juſtum eſt petito, vel quod videatur honeſtum:
Nam ſtultum petere eſt, quod poſſit jure negari.

lg.head: 32. Nota ignotis non commutanda.
lg.l: Ignotum tibi nolito praeponere notis:
Cognita judicio conſtant, incognita caſu.

lg.head:
33. Dies quiſ
que ſupremus putandus.
lg.l: Cum dubia incertis verſetur vita periclis,

Pro lucro tibi pone diem quicun
que laboras.

lg.head: 34. Obſecundandum amicis.
lg.l: Vincere cum poſſis, interdum cede ſodali,
Obſequio quoniam dulces vincuntur amici.

lg.head: 35. Amieitiae mutua officia.
lg.l: Ne dubites, cum magua petas, impendere parva:
His etenim rebus conjungit Gratia chares.

lg.head: 36. Amicitia rixas odit.
lg.l: Litem inferre cave, cum quo tibi gratia juncta eſt,
Ira odium generat, concordia nutrit amorem.

lg.head: 37. Caſtgatio ſine ira.
lg.l: Servorum ob culpam cum te dolor urget in iram,
Ipſe tibi moderare, tuis ut parcere poſſis.

lg.head: 38. Patientiâ vincere.
lg.l: Quem ſuperare potes, interdum vince ferendo:
Maxima enim mo • am ſemper patientia virtus.

lg.head: 39. Quaeſita ſunt conſervanda.
lg.l: Conſerva potius quae ſunt jam parta labore:
Cum labor in damno eſt, creſcit mortalis egeſtas.

lg.head: 40 Conſulendum tibi imprimis.
lg.l: Cum fueris felix, ſemper tibi proximus eſto.

lg.head: We are to deſerve well of all men.
lg.l: Be courteous unto all; a friend to gain
Is better than a kingdom to obtain.

lg.head: 2. Search not after ſecret things.
lg.l: To know God's ſecrets do not thou deſire;
Since thou art earthly, earthly things acquire.

lg.head: 3. The fear of death doth baniſh joy.
lg.l: A fool he is who feareth his death-bed;
Who thinks of death, to th' joyes of life is dead.

lg.head: 4. Beware of Anger.
lg.l: Diſpute not when th'art angry; rage doth blind
Thy ſight of truth, and ſuffocate thy mind.

lg.head: 5. We muſt be free when there is occaſion.
lg.l: When opportunity doth ask, be free:
When time requires, ſomething muſt given be.

lg.head: 6. A moderate fortune is moſt ſafe.
lg.l: Riches avoid, let poverty prevail;
That Ship's moſt ſafe on a ſmall Sea doth ſail.

lg.head: 7. Secret vices are to be conceal'd.
lg.l: Blaze not thy Vice, that many may not blame
That which unto your ſelf you think a ſhame.

lg.head: 8. All ſecrets at length are diſcovered.
lg.l: Let no one think by vice the vicious win;
Though for a time 'tis hid, yet time ſhews ſin.

lg.head: 9. The weakneſs of the Body is ſupply'd by the ſtrength of Vertue.
lg.l: Contemn not him who weakneſs undergoes;
Though ſhe no ſtrength, yet nature wit beſtows.

lg.head: 10. We must yield to the ſtronger for a time.
lg.l: A While to thy Superiours yield; oft we
The Victor conquer'd by the vanquiſht ſee.

lg.head: 11. We muſt not ſcold with our friends.
lg.l: Contend not with thy Friend let me adviſe;
For oft from ſmall words doth great diſcord riſe.

lg.head: 12. Inquire not thy Fortune by lot.
lg.l: Ask not the lot what God doth ordinate;
Without thy Counſel he doth rule thy fate.

lg.head: 13. Too much bravery begets envy.
lg.l: Shun being too brave, and envy ſo; although
It doth no harm, 'tis hard to undergo.

lg.head: 14. Be not caſt down when overcome by Injuſtice.
lg.l: Droop not though by Injuſtice wrong'd th'aſt bin;
He doth not long rejoycce who ſo doth win.

lg.head: 15. Friends reconcil'd muſt forget former injuries.
lg.l: Tell not paſt wrath; an evil tongue doth ſow
Old enmity, and friendſhip overthrough.

lg.head: 16. Neither prayſe nor disprayſe thy ſelf.
lg.l: Nor prayſe, nor blame thy ſelf; fools ſo dilate
Themſelves, when by vain glory urg'd they prate.

lg.head: 17. Thriſtineſs.
lg.l: Be frugal in thy wealth; that which we may
Be long a getting, ſwiftly ſlides away.

lg.head: 18. Severity of Carriage is ſometimes to be laid aſide.
lg.l: When time behooves, a ſeeming fool then be,
'Tis wiſedome and not fooliſhneſs in thee.

lg.head: 19. Be neither prod gal nor coveto is.
lg.l: Be free, not Prodigal; if otherwiſe
You uſe your wealth, your fame will never riſe.

lg.head: 20. We muſt give little credit to one who talks much.
lg.l: Sometimes him not believe who doth relate
Of others; truſt not him who ſtill doth prate.

lg.head: 21. Let not the Drunkard blame the Wine.
lg.l: When drunk, thy ſelf not pardon for the ſame;
There's no fault in the Wine, the Driuker blame.

lg.head: 22. Communicate thy Couſel to thy Friend.
lg.l: Freely thy mind unto thy Friend relate,
And tell thy Doctor of thy Bodies ſtate.

lg.head: 23. Repine not at the good ſucceſſe of bad men.
lg.l: When bad men win, wiſh not their overthrow;
Fortune doth raiſe them, but to fall more low.

lg.head: 24. We muſt provide for future fortune.
lg.l: Foreſee thy fate; that chance doth fall more light
That is provided for by thy foreſight.

lg.head: 25. Live by hope.
lg.l: Though ſometime Fortune frown, yet Hope retain;
It only doth with thee till death remain.

lg.head: 26. Take time by the forelock.
lg.l: Then ſtir when opportunity is faire;
Behind, time's bald, his forehead's full of hair.

lg.head: 27. Gueſſe at the future by time paſt.
lg.l: Times future, and the next enſuing fate
Foreſee by paſt time; Janus imitate.

lg.head: 28. We muſt live by the rules of reaſon.
lg.l: From pleaſure ſpare, wealth on thy health beſtow;
Then unto pleaſure more to health we owe,

lg.head: 29. Sometimes agree with the multitude.
lg.l: Contemn not alwaies what the rout adviſe,
You none can pleaſe, while you do all deſpiſe;

lg.head: 30. Take care of thy health.
lg.l: 'Bove all things value health, thy chief good; know
If ill thy ſelf, not ſeaſons make thee ſo.

lg.head: 31. Credit not dreams.
lg.l: Regard not dreams, for ſleeping, thy ſhut eyes
Do ſeem to ſee what waking you deviſe.

lg.head: De omnibus bene merendum.
lg.l: Si potes, ignotis etiam prodeſſe memento;
Utilius regno, meritis acquirere amicos.

lg.head: 2. Arcana non ſcrutanda.
lg.l:
Mitte arcana Dei, coelum
que inquirere quid ſit:
Cum ſis mortalis, quae ſunt mortalia cura.

lg.head: 3. Mortis timor gaudia pellit.
lg.l: Liuque metum Lethi, nam ſtultum; tempore in omni
Dum mortem metuas, amittis gaudia vitae.

lg.head: 4. Iracundia cavenda.
lg.l: Iratus de re incerta contendere noli:
Impedit ira animum ne poſſit cernere verum.

lg.head: 5. Expendendum ubi opus oſt.
lg.l: Fac ſumptum propere, cum res deſiderat ipſa:
Dandum etenim eſt aliquid cum tempus poſtulat aut res.

lg.head: 6. Fortuna modica tutior.
lg.l: Quod nimium eſt fugito, parvo gaudere memento.
Tuta mage eſt puppis modico quae flumine fertur.

lg.head: 7. Occulta vitia reticenda.
lg.l: Quod pudeat, ſocies prudens celare memento,
Nr plures culpent id quod tibi displicet uni.

lg.head: 8. Occulta tandem revelantur.
lg.l: Nolo putes pravos homines peccare lucrari:
Temporibus peccata latent, & tempore parent.

lg.head: 9. Inbecillitas virtute compenſatur.
lg.l: Corporis exigui vires contemnere noli:
Conſilio pollet, cu. vim natura negavit.

lg.head: 10. Cedendum potentiori ad tempus.
lg.l: Quem ſcieris non eſſe parem tibi, tempore cede:
Victorem à victo ſuperari ſaepe videmus.

lg.head: 11. Rixandum cum familiaribus.
lg.l: Adverſus notum noli contendere verbis,
Lis minimis verbis interdum maxima creſcit.

lg.head: 12. Fortuna non quaerenda ſorte.
lg.l: Quod Deus intendat, noli perquirere ſorte;
Quid ſtatuit de te, fine te deliberat ipſe.

lg.head: 13. Luxus odium generat.
lg.l: Invidiam nimio cultu vitare memento:
Quae ſi non laedit, tamen hanc ſufferre moleſtum eſt.

lg.head: 14. Animus non deponendus ob iniquum judicium.
lg.l: Eſto animo forti cum ſis damnatus inique:
Nemo diu gaudet qui judice vincit iniquo.

lg.head: 15. Reconciliatis lis non refricanda.
lg.l: Litis praeteritae noli maledicta referre:
Poſt inimicitias iram meminiſſe malorum est.

lg.head: 16. Teipſum neque lauda, neque culpa.
lg.l: Nec te collaudes, nec te culpaveris ipſe:
Hoc faciunt ſtulti quos gloria vexat inanis.

lg.head: 17. Parſimonia.
lg.l: Utere quaeſitis modice, dum ſumptus abundat;
Labitur exiguo, quod partum eſt tempore longe.

lg.head: 18. Supercilium nonnunquam deponendum.
lg.l: Inſipiens eſto cum tempus poſtulat aut res;
Stultitiam ſimulare loco prudentia ſumma eſt.

lg.head: 19. Neque prodigus, neque avaius.
lg.l: Luxuriam fugito, fimul & vitare memento
Crimen avacritiae; nam ſunt contraria famae.

lg.head: 20. Loquaci parum credendum.
lg.l: Nolito quaedam referenti credere ſemper:
Exigua eſt tribuenda fides, qui mu ta loquuatur.

lg.head: 21. Ebrius vinun non accuſet.
lg.l: Q • od potu peccas, ignoſcere tu tibi noli:
Nam nullum crimen vim eſt, ſed culpa bibentis.

lg.head: 22. Amicis concilia credenda.
lg.l: Conſilium arcanum tacito committe ſodali:
Corports auxilium medico committe fideli.

lg.head: 23. Succeſſus malorum ne te offendat.
lg.l: Succeſſum in lignis noli (tu) ferre moleſte;
Indulget fortuna malis ut laedere poſſit.

lg.head: 24. Futurus caſus providendus.
lg.l: Prospice, qui veniunt hos caſus eſſe ferendos:
Nam levius laedit quicquid praevideris ante.

lg.head: 25. Animus in adverſis ſpe fovendus.
lg.l: Rebus in adverſis animum ſubmittere noli:
Spem retine: ſpes una hominem nec morte relinquit.

lg.head: 26. Opportunitas cum contingit, tenends.
lg.l: Rem tibi quam neſcis apt •• , demittere noli:
Fronte capillata, poſt eſt occaſio calva.

lg.head: 27. Futura ex praeteritis colligenda.
lg.l: Quod ſequitur ſpecta, quodque imminet ante videte;
Illum imitare deum qui partem ſpectat utramque.

lg.head: 28. Vitae ratio habenda.
lg.l: Fortior ut valeas, interdum parcior eſto:
Pauca voluptati debentur, plura ſaluti.

lg.head: 29. Multitudine cedendum.
lg.l: Judicium populi nunquam contempſeris unus,
Ne nulli placeas, dum vis contemnere multos.

lg.head: 30. Valetudo curanda.
lg.l: Sit tibi praecipue, quod primum eſt, cura ſalutis.
Tempora ne culpes, cum ſis tibi cauſa doloris.

lg.head: 31. Somnia non obſervanda.
lg.l: Somnia ne cures: nam mens humana quod optat,
Cum vigilat ſperans per ſomnum cernit ad ipſum.

lg.head: When thou doſt well, fear not evil report.
lg.l: Doing well, though thee men ſhould defame and wrong,
Care not; we cannot rule anothers tongue.

lg.head: 2. Conceal thy Friend's fault.
lg.l: Keep thy Friend'y credit being a witneſs; yet
Diſcredit not thy ſelf in doing it.

lg.head: 3. Supect fair words.
lg.l: Fair words ſuſpect; the ſimple truth is ſpoke
Naked, but fraud doth alwayes were a Cloak.

lg.head: 4. Fly Idleneſs.
lg.l: Shun Idleneſs, the mind being un-imploy'd,
The body with diſeaſes is annoy'd.

lg.head: 5. Let not the mind alwaies ſtand bent.
lg.l: Joyes intermingle thou with Cares, and ſo
Thy heavy labours will the lighter ſhew.

lg.head: 6. Reprehend none with an evil mind.
lg.l: Carp not at what another man doth do,
He thee may jear, and in the ſame way too.

lg.head: 7. Increaſe thy eſtate.
lg.l: What the laſt Will gives keep, leaſt fame you call,
If you increaſe it not, a Prodigall.

lg.head: 8. Let old age be bountifull.
lg.l: What in thine old age fortune doth beſtow,
Unto thy friend as freely let it go.

lg.head: 9. Regard the Speech, and not the Speaker.
lg.l: Contemn not Councel if not bad; deſpiſe
Not Maſter, what thy Servant doth adviſe.

lg.head: 10. Be content with thy preſent fortune.
lg.l: If thou haſt loſt thine old inheritance,
Be ſtill content, grieve not at adverſe chance.

lg.head: 11. Marry not for riches.
lg.l: For love of gain, nor wed, nor keep a ſhrew;
Rather than keep her, let her dowry go.

lg.head: 12. Let anothers example teach thee wiſdome.
lg.l: Learn by th' examples other men do give;
Anothers life doth teach us how to live.

lg.head: 13. Attempt nothing againſt thy ſtrength.
lg.l: That which thou canſt compleat, begin, leaſt thy
Too heavy work as ſoon as born ſhould dy.

lg.head: 14. Silence doth conſent.
lg.l: Conceal not what's ill done, leaſt you are thought
Concealing it the Author of the fault.

lg.head: 15. Laws rigor is to be tempered with equity.
lg.l: From unjuſt law unto the juſt Judge fly;
Juſtice, the Law it ſelf ſhould rectifie.

lg.head: 16. Be patient under deſerved Affliction.
lg.l: Unto Croſs fate come by thy fault ſubmit,
Being guilty ſo, puniſh thy ſelf for it.

lg.head: 17. Read, but with judgement.
lg.l: Having read much, read more; wonder you may,
Believe not though all which the Poets ſay.

lg.head: 18. Speak modeſtly in thy Cups.
lg.l: Uſe few words 'fore thy Gueſts, leaſt men eſteem
Thee talkative, whilſt thou wouldſt witty ſeem.

lg.head: 19. Regard not thy Wife's anger.
lg.l: Fear not thy Wife being angry, tears do then,
It is their Nature, prove the ſnares of men.

lg.head: 20. Uſe thy Eſtate, but do not abuſe it.
lg.l: Abuſe not what thou haſt; he who doth ſpend
His own, covets the money of his friend.

lg.head: 21. Fear not death.
lg.l: Welcome approaching death, Atropos knife
Doth end thy cares when it doth end thy life.

lg.head: 22. If thy wife be profitable, regard not her tongue.
lg.l: If thy Wife's talkative, the fault's in thee,
If thou not ſilent art, as ſhe ſhould be.

lg.head: 23. Love thy Parents.
lg.l: Not with ſlight piety thy Parents love,
Nor ſowre to her, while ſweet to him you prove.

lg.head: Recte agendo aliorum linguam ne timeas.
lg.l: Cum recte vivas, ne cures verba malorum;
Arbitrii noſtri non est quid quiſque loquatur.

lg.head: 2. Amici crimen celandum.
lg.l: Productus teſtis, ſalvo tamen ante pudore,
Quantumcunque potes celato crimen amici.

lg.head: 3. Blandiloqu • ntia ſuſpecta.
lg.l: Sermones blandos blaeſoſque cavere memiato:
Simplicitas veri ſana eſt, fraus ficta loquendi.

lg.head: 4. Ignava vita fugienda.
lg.l: Segnitiem fugito, quae vitae ignavia fertur:
Nam cum ammus languet, conſumit inertia corpus.

lg.head: 5. Animus feſſus relaxandus.
lg.l: Interpone this interdum gaudia curis,
Ut poſſis animo quemvis ſufferre laborem.

lg.head: 6. Malo animo neminem reprehendas.
lg.l: Alterius dictum aut factum ne carpſeris unquam,
Exemplo ſimili ne te derideat alter.

lg.head: 7. Haereditas augenda.
lg.l: Quae tibi ſors dederit tobulis ſuprema notato,
Augendo ſerva, ne ſis quem fama loquatur.

lg.head: 8. Senectus ſit munifica.
lg.l: Cum tibi divitiae ſuperant in fiae ſenectae,
Munificus facito vivas, non parcus amicis.

lg.head: 9. Verba attendenda, non os loquentis.
lg.l: Utile conſilium dominus ne deſpice ſervi:
Nullius ſenſum, ſi prodeſt, tempſeris unquam.

lg.head: 10. Praeſenti utendum fortuna.
lg.l: Rebus & in cenſu, ſi non eſt, quod fuit ante;
Fac vivas contentus to quod tempora praebent.

lg.head: 11. Vxor ſpe dotis non ducenda.
lg.l: Uxorem fuge, ne ducas ſub nomine dotis;
Nec retinere velis ſi coeperit eſſe moleſta.

lg.head: 12. Alieno ſapete exemplo.
lg.l: Multorum diſce exemplo, quae facta ſequaris,
Quoe fugias: vita eſt nobis aliena magiſtra.

lg.head: 13. Nihil ultra vires.
lg.l: Quod potes, id tentes: operis ne pondere preſſus
Succumbat labor, & fruſtra tentata relinquas.

lg.head: 14. Conſentire videcur qui tacet.
lg.l: Quod noſti haud recte factum nolito tacere,
Ne videare malos imitari velle tacendo.

lg.head: 15. Rigor favore temperandus.
lg.l: Judicis auxilium ſub iniqua lege rogato:
Ipſae etenim leges cupiunt ut jure regantur.

lg.head: 16. Feras quae culpa tua pateris.
lg.l: Quod merito pateris, patienter ferre memento:
Cumque reus tibi ſis, ipſum te judice damn.

lg.head: 17. Multa legenda, ſed cum judicio.
lg.l: Mult a legas facito, perlectis perlege multa;
Nam miranda eanunt ſed non credenda Poetae.

lg.head: 18. Modeſte in convivio legendum.
lg.l: Inter convivas fac ſis ſermone modeſtus:
Ne dicare loquax, dum vis urbanus haberi.

lg.head: 19. Iracundia uxoris non formidanda.
lg.l: Conjugis iratae noli tu verba timere:
Nam lacrymis ſtruit inſidias, dum foemina plorat.

lg.head: 20. Quaeſiis utendum, non abutendum.
lg.l: Utere qnaeſitis, ſed ne videaris abuti:
Qui ſua couſumunt, cum deest, aliena ſequuntur.

lg.head: 21. Mors non formidanda.
lg.l: Fac tibi proponas mortem non eſse tenendam,
Quae bona ſi non eſt, finis tamen ill a malorum.

lg.head: 23. Uxor loquax, ſi proba, ferenda.
lg.l: Uxoris linguam, ſi frugi eſt, ferre memento:
Namque malum eſt nil velle pati, nec poſſe tacere.

lg.head: 23. Pietas etga parentes.
lg.l: Dilige non aegra charos pietate parentes:
Nec matrem offendas, dum vis bonus eſſe parenti.

lg.head: Contemn Riches.
lg.l: Riches deſpiſe, if a rich mind you'l have;
Who admires Money, is to it a ſlave.

lg.head: 2. It is beſt to live according to the rules of nature.
lg.l: Nature will alwayes give what doth befit,
If you're content, and ask no more then it.

lg.head: 3. Manage thy affairs with reaſon.
lg.l: Wanting fore-ſight you hard fate undergo,
Say not that fortune's blind, 'tis you are ſo.

lg.head: 4. Love Riches but for their uſe only.
lg.l: Money for preſent uſe, not ſhew, require;
Holy and honeſt men no more deſire.

lg.head: 5. Spare not thy riches on thy health.
lg.l: When thou haſt money, ſpend it on thy health;
Sick rich men want themſelves, although no wealth.

lg.head: 6. Suffer a fatherly chaſtiſement.
lg.l: If you a Maſter's ſtripes can bear, receive
And welcome more what thy vext-Parents give.

lg.head: 7. Attempt certain and profitable things.
lg.l: What certain profit gives, let that be done;
Erroncous things and things uncertain ſhun.

lg.head: 8. Give freely.
lg.l: Give freely that that's ask'd if able; know
Thou doſt gain well, when thou doſt well beſtow.

lg.head: 9. A Suſpition is to be examin'd incontinently.
lg.l: Quickly the truth inquire that you ſuſpect;
Dangers come ſwift when uſher'd by neglect.

lg.head: 10. Venus is to be overcome by abſtinence.
lg.l: When you to dangerous Venus condeſcend,
Be not a glutten to the Belly's friend.

lg.head: 11. A had man is the worst wilde beaſt.
lg.l: Each Animal is fear'd though ne're ſo ſmall;
But I adviſe fear one man more than all.

lg.head: 12. Prefer Wiſdome to Strength.
lg.l: If Nature ſtrength, wiſdome your ſelf beſtow
Upon your ſelf, and a true valour ſo.

lg.head: 13. A Friend is the Mind's Phyſician.
lg.l: Help from thy Friend deſire when thou art ill;
A faithfull Friend is the beſt Doctor ſtill.

lg.head: 14. A broken heart is the beſt ſacrifice.
lg.l: Why doth the harmleſs beaſt, when you ſin, bleed?
Folly, to think his blood doth cleanſe thy deed.

lg.head: 15. Chooſe a Friend for manners.
lg.l: When for a faithfull friend you do enquire,
One rich in nothing but in mind deſire.

lg.head: 16. Shun Avarice.
lg.l: Vſe Fortune's gift; what do you gain when ſhe
Doth Plenty give, yet live in Poverty?

lg.head: 17. Pleaſure is an enemy to a good name.
lg.l: If you would have Fame prayſe what you have done,
It will, if you diſhoneſt pleaſures ſhun.

lg.head: 18. Mock not Old age.
lg.l: Mock not the faults which in Old age you find,
For each Old body hath a Childiſh mind.

lg.head: 19. Riches are mortal, Art immortal.
lg.l: Thou ſomething learn; fickle wealth flyes away,
But Art remaining fixt with thee doth ſtay.

lg.head: 20. Manners are known by words.
lg.l: Mind what is ſlyly ſaid; for ſuch words do
Diſcover manners and conceal them too.

lg.head: 21. Art is to be helpt by uſe.
lg.l: Though thou haſt gain'd an Art, ſtill practiſe it:
Uſe helps the hand, as ſtudy doth the wit.

lg.head: 22. The contempt of life.
lg.l: Value not much th' approach of thy laſt hour;
Who contemns life, fears not death's fatal power.

lg.head: 23. Learn, and teach.
lg.l: Learn of the Learn'd, teach the unlearned fry:
The Doctrine of good things, ſo, multiply.

lg.head: 24. Drink with reaſon.
lg.l: Drink but what's neceſſary, ſhun exceſs;
Oft a Diſeaſe comes by Voluptuouſneſſe.

lg.head: 25. Condemn not that which thou haſt approved of.
lg.l: That diſapprove not which you prays'd; be free
From being guilty of inconſtancy.

lg.head: 26. Be circumspect in both Fortunes.
lg.l: When the calm ſmiles of Fortune raiſe thy ſtate,
Beware a change; if bad, hope better fate.

lg.head: 27. Wiſdome doth increaſe by ſtudy.
lg.l: Ceaſe not to learn; Wiſdome by it is known;
By the long uſe of time 'tis ſeldome ſhown.

lg.head: 28. Praiſe sparingly.
lg.l: Praiſe ſparingly; one day will certain ſhew
Whether the often prays'd be friend, or no.

lg.head: 29. Be not aſham'd to learn.
lg.l: 'Tis no diſgrace to learn an Art unknown;
Knowledge deſerves much prayſe, ignorance none.

lg.head: 30. Uſe Sobriety in all things.
lg.l: Pleaſure, and Strife, Venus, and Bacchus move;
Enjoy the good effects, bad diſapprove.

lg.head: 31. Truſt not the ſad, and filent.
lg.l: Who ſilent is and melancholly, ſhun;
Smooth and untroubled the deep Rivers run.

lg.head: 32 Compare thy Fortune with another mans.
lg.l: When you complain, mind others fate, and ſee
In what reſpect Fortune's mote harſh to thee.

lg.head: 33. Attempt nothing beyond thy ſtrength.
lg.l: Begin what you to finiſh need not fail;
Safer ith' Haven 'tis than Main to ſail.

lg.head: 34. Be juſt to the juſt.
lg.l: Be juſt unto good men, for oft no ſmall
And yet juſt judgements on the unjuſt fall.

lg.head: 35. Equally bear both Fortunes.
lg.l: Do not complain when thy Eſtate doth fall,
Rather rejoyce that ill fate takes not all.

lg.head: 36. Bear with thy Friend.
lg.l: Great loſſe is great vexation, yet there are
Some things the which true Friends ſhould patient bear.

lg.head: 37. Truſt not to time.
lg.l: Promiſe not many dayes, few, ſhort, they be;
Death, ſhadow-like doth alwayes follow thee.

lg.head: 38. What Sacrifice doth pleaſe God.
lg.l: God loves not blood, his Altars do not ſtain;
Incenſe to Heaven, the Calf to earth ordain.

lg.head: 39. Conceal thy dammage receiv'd of a great one.
lg.l: To Fortune yield wrong'd by her Favourite;
For he again may riſe who can ſubmit.

lg.head: 40. Chaſtiſe thy ſelf.
lg.l: Puniſh thy ſelf when thou a ſinner art;
The ſmart of wounds is cur'd by adding ſmart.

lg.head: 41. Diſapprove not of thy changed friend.
lg.l: An Old friend diſapprove not; though he be
Now chang'd, yet think what he was once to thee.

lg.head: 42. Make uſe of a good turn.
lg.l: Be thankfull unto him thy friend hath been,
Leaſt you the Sirname of Ingratefull win.

lg.head: 43. Be not ſuſpicious.
lg.l: Who are ſuſpicious, miſerable are;
Such dying once dye to perpetual fear.

lg.head: 44. Be a man to thy man.
lg.l: When you do Servants buy, although you will
Them Servants call, know they are human ſtill.

lg.head: 45. Take hold of occaſion.
lg.l: The firſt occaſion take, leaſt you again
Loſt opportunity re-ask in vain.

lg.head: 46. Rejoyce not at ſodain death.
lg.l: At Bad men's ſodain death Joy do not ſhew;
They only well do dye who did live ſo.

lg.head: 47. Iſ married, ſhun acquaintance.
lg.l: Having a Wife, ſhun thou a feined Friend,
Who thy few goods and richer fame may ſpend.

lg.head: 48. Alwaies learn.
lg.l: Though learned, yet ſtill learn, and ſhun the will
Of being unwilling to be Scholar ſtill.

lg.head: 49. Brevity helps memory.
lg.l: You ask why I this way of writing take;
Know brevity did bid me Diſticks make.

lg.head: Divitiarum contemptus.
lg.l: Despice divitias, ſi vis animo eſſe beatus;
Quas qui ſuſpiciunt, mendicant ſemper avari.

lg.head: 2. Vivere ad naturam optimum.
lg.l: Commoda naturae nullo tibi tempore deerunt,
Si contentus eo fueris, quod poſtulat uſus,

lg.head: 3. Res ratione agendae.
lg.l: Cum ſis incautus, nec rem ratione gubernes,
Noli fortunam, quae non eſt, dicere coecam.

lg.head: 4. Amor pecuniae ad uſum.
lg.l: Dilige denarium, ſed parce dilige formam:
Quam nemo ſanctus, nec honeſtus captat habere?

lg.head: 5. In valetudine ne opibus parcas.
lg.l: Cum fueris locuples, corpus curare memento.
Aeger dives habet nummos, ſed non habet ipſum.

lg.head: 6. Caſtigatio paterna ferenda.
lg.l: Verbera cum tuleris diſcens aliquando magiſtri,
Fer patris imperium cum verbis exit in iram.

lg.head: 7. Certa & utilia agenda.
lg.l: Res age quae proſunt: rurſus vitare memento,
In quibus error inest, nec spes eſt certa laboris.

lg.head: 8. Libenter donandum.
lg.l: Quo donare potes, gratis concede roganti:
Nam recte feciſſe bonis in parte lucrorum eſt.

lg.head: 9. Suſpitio ſtatim expedienda.
lg.l: Quid tibi ſuspectum eſt, confeſtim diſcute quid ſit:
Namque ſolent, primo quae ſunt neglecta, nocere.

lg.head: 10. Venus abſtinentia cohibenda.
lg.l: Cum te detineat Veneris damnoſa voluptas,
Indulgere gulae noli, quae ventris amica eſt.

lg.head: 11. Homo malus, fera peſſima.
lg.l: Cum tibi proponas animalia cuncta timere,
Unum hominem tibi praecipio plus eſse timendum.

lg.head: 12. Sapientia fortitudini praeferenda.
lg.l: Cum tibi praevalidae faeriut in corpore vires,
Fac ſapias, ſic tu poteris vir ſortis haberi.

lg.head: 13. Amicus cordi medicus.
lg.l: Auxilium à not is petito ſi forte laboras;
Nec quiſquam melior medicus quam fidus amicus.

lg.head: 14. Sacrificium, ſpiritus contribulatus.
lg.l: Cum ſis ipſe nocens, moritur cur victima pro te?
Scultitia eſt morte alterius sperare ſalutem.

lg.head: 15. Amicus ex moribus diligendus.
lg.l: Cum tibi vel ſocium vel fidum quaeris amicum,
Nón tibi fortuna eſt hominis, ſed vita petenda.

lg.head: 16. Avaritia vitanda.
lg.l: Utere quaeſitis opibus, fuge nomen avari:
Quid tibi divitiae proſunt, ſi pauper abundas?

lg.head: 17. Voluptas inimica famae.
lg.l: Si famam ſervare cupis, dum vivis, honeſtam,
Fac fugias animo, quae ſunt mala gaudia vitae.

lg.head: 18. Senem etiam delirum ne irriſeris.
lg.l: Cum ſapias animo, noli irridere ſenectam;
Nam quicunque ſenex, ſenſus puerilis in illo eſt.

lg.head: 19. Opes fluxae, ars perpetua.
lg.l: Diſce aliquid; nam cum ſubito fortuna recedit,
Ars remanet, vitamque hominis non deſerit unquam.

lg.head: 20. Mores ex verbis cogniti.
lg.l: Omnia perspicito tacitus, quae quiſque loquatur.
Sermo hominum mores & celat, & indicat idem.

lg.head: 21. Ars uſu juvanda.
lg.l: Exerce ſtudium, quamvis perceperis artem.
Ut cura ingemum, ſic & manus adjuvat uſum.

lg.head: 22. Virae contemptus.
lg.l: Multum ne cures venturis tempor a lethi;
Non timet is mortem qui ſcit contemnere vitam.

lg.head: 23. Diſcendum & Docendum.
lg.l: Diſce ſed à doctis, indoctos ipſe doceto:
Propaganda etenim rerum doctrina bonarum.

lg.head: 24. Bibendi ratio.
lg.l: Hoc bibe quod profit, ſi tu vis vivere ſanus:
Morbi cauſa mali eſt homini quandoque voluptas.

lg.head: 25. No damnes quod probaveris.
lg.l: Laudaris quodcunque palam, quodcunque probaris,
Hoc vide ue rurſus levitatis crimine damnes.

lg.head: 26. Circumſpectus ſis in utraque fortuna.
lg.l: Tranquillis rebus quae ſunt adverſa caveto:
Burſus in adverſis melius ſperare memento.

lg.head: 27. Studio creſcit ſapientia.
lg.l: Dicere ne ceſſes; cura ſapientia creſcit;
Rara datur longo prudentia temporis uſu.

lg.head: 28. Parce laudandum.
lg.l: Parce laudato: nam quem tu ſaepe probaris,
Una dies, qualis fuerit, monſtrabit, amicus.

lg.head: 29. Diſcere ne pudeat.
lg.l: Ne pudeat quae neſcieris, te velle doceri.
Scire aliquid laus eſt; pudor eſt nil diſcere velle.

lg.head: 30. Rebus utendum ad ſobrietatem.
lg.l: Cum Venere & Baccho lis eſt, & junct a voluptas;
Quod lautum eſt animo complectere, ſed fege lites.

lg.head: 31. Triſtibus & tacitis non fidendum.
lg.l: Demiſſos animo, ac tacitos vitare memento:
Qua flumen placidum eſt, forſan latet altius unda.

lg.head: 32. Sors ſorti conferenda.
lg.l: Cum tibi diſpliceat rerum fortuna tuarum,
Alterius specta, quo ſis diſcrimine pejor.

lg.head: 33. Vltra vires nihil aggrediendum.
lg.l: Quod potes id tenta; nam littus carpere remis
Tutius est multo, quam velum tendere in altum.

lg.head: 34. Cum juſto inique non contendendum.
lg.l: Contra hominem juſtum prave contendere noſi;
Semper enim Deus injuſtas ulciſcitur iras.

lg.head: 35. Fotuna utraque aeque ferenda.
lg.l: Ereptis opibus noli gaudere querendo:
Sed gaude potius, tibi ſi contingat habere.

lg.head: 36. Ab amico quid ferendum.
lg.l: Eſt jactura gravis, quae ſunt amittere damnis:
Sunt quaedam, quae ferre docet patienter amicum.

lg.head: 37. Tempori non confidendum.
lg.l: Tempora longa tibi noli promittere vitae:
Quocunque ingrederis, ſequitur mors corporis umbra.

lg.head: 38. Deus quibus placandus.
lg.l: Thure Deum placa, vittulum ſine creſcat aratro;
Ne credas placare Deum, dum caede litatur.

lg.head: 39. A potentioribus laeſus diſſimula.
lg.l: Caede locum laeſus fortunae, cede potenti:
Laedere qui potuit, prodeſſe aliquando valebit.

lg.head: 40. Caſtiga teipſum.
lg.l: Cum quid peccaris, caſtiga te ipſe ſubinde.
Vulnera dum ſanas, dolor eſt medicina doloris.

lg.head: 41. Amicus mutatus, non vituperandus.
lg.l: Damnaris nunquam poſt longum tempus amicum:
Mutavit mores, ſed pignora prima memento.

lg.head: 42. Beneficiorum collatio attendenda.
lg.l: Gratior officiis quo ſis mage, charior eſto:
Ne nomen ſubeas, quod dicitur officiperda.

lg.head: 43. Suſpitionem tolle.
lg.l: Suspectus caveas, ne ſis miſer omnibus horis;
Nam timidis & ſuspectis aptiſſima mors eſt.

lg.head: 44. Humanitas erga ſervos.
lg.l: Cum ſueris ſervos proprios mercatus in uſus,
Et famulos dicas, homines tamen eſſe memento.

lg.head: 45. Occaſionem rei commodae ne praetermittas.
lg.l: Quam primum rapienda tibi est occaſio prima,
Ne rurſus quaeras quae jam neglexeris ante.

lg.head: 46. Non laetandum de repentino obitu.
lg.l: Morte repentina noli gaudere malorum:
Faelices obeunt, quorum ſine crimine vita eſt.

lg.head: 47. Pauper ſimulatum viter amicum.
lg.l: Cum conjux tibi ſit, nec res, & ſama laboret,
Vitandum ducas mimicum nomen amici.

lg.head: 48. Junge ſtudium.
lg.l: Cum tibi contingat ſtudio cognoſcere multa,
Fac diſcas multa, & vites non velle doceri.

lg.head: 49. Brevitas memoriae amica.
lg.l: Miraris verbis nudis me ſcribere verſus?
Hos brevitas ſenſus fecit conjungere binos.
